docs.title: Master Python Curriculum
docs.text:
Welcome to the Master Python Curriculum, an open-source learning project designed to take you from absolute beginner in Python all the way to advanced programming and even quantum computing.

This is not just another tutorial series. It is a structured curriculum with volumes, chapters, and projects — designed for gradual learning.

docs.title: 📚 What You Will Learn
docs.text:
The curriculum is divided into 8 volumes:

  1. Python Foundations — Learn the basics of Python, data types, control flow, functions, file handling, and OOP. ✅ Fully available now.

  2. Python for Web Development — Frameworks like Flask, Django, and FastAPI. 🚧 Under construction.

  3. Python for Data Science — NumPy, pandas, visualization, machine learning. 🚧 Under construction.

  4. System Automation and DevOps — Automation, CI/CD, cloud, and infrastructure scripting. 🚧 Under construction.

  5. Application Development — GUI, desktop, and cross-platform app development. 🚧 Under construction.

  6. Advanced Python — Concurrency, metaprogramming, design patterns, and performance. 🚧 Under construction.

  7. Data Structures and Algorithms — Core CS concepts implemented in Python. 🚧 Under construction.

  8. Quantum Computing — Explore quantum computing using Python libraries like Qiskit. 🚧 Under construction.

docs.title: 🚀 How to Get Started
docs.text:
• Begin with Volume 1: Python Foundations.
  • Each chapter is short and focused on one concept.
  • At the end of each volume, a Capstone Project brings everything together.

docs.title: 🧑‍🤝‍🧑 Open Source and Community
docs.text:
This curriculum is open-source and will grow with community contributions. You can help by fixing typos, improving explanations, or writing new chapters.

See the contributing guide here: CONTRIBUTING.md

docs.title: 📖 License
docs.text:
• Educational content -> CC-BY-SA 4.0
  • Code examples -> MIT License

docs.title: 👤 Author
docs.text:
Created and maintained by Deepak Nair LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/dhnair

If you find this project useful, please share it with others and check back for updates!

docs.title: Contributing Guidelines
docs.text: Thank you for considering contributing to the Master Python Curriculum project! This project is open-source and welcomes contributions of all kinds.

docs.title: How to Contribute
docs.text:
1. Fork the repository on GitHub.
  2. Create a new branch for your changes: git checkout -b feature/my-feature
  3. Make your changes in Markdown (.md) files or Python code snippets.
  4. Commit your changes with a clear commit message: git commit -m "Add explanation of list comprehensions"
  5. Push your changes to your fork: git push origin feature/my-feature
  6. Open a Pull Request on the main repository.

docs.title: Style Guidelines
docs.text:
• All chapters must be written in Markdown (.md).
  • Use only ASCII-safe characters in filenames.
  • File names must use lowercase letters, numbers, and underscores (no spaces).
  • Each chapter should include:
  • A clear title and chapter number
  • Section headers for organization
  • Code examples in fenced code blocks (```python)
  • A short "Next Steps" section linking to the next chapter

docs.title: Licensing
docs.text:
• Educational content (Markdown, text, images) is licensed under CC-BY-SA 4.0.
  • Code examples (Python snippets) are licensed under the MIT License.
  • By submitting a contribution, you agree to dual-license your work under the same terms.

docs.title: Code of Conduct
docs.text:
• Be respectful and constructive in discussions.
  • Criticism should be aimed at ideas, not individuals.
  • Help create a welcoming environment for learners and contributors.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: If you are unsure about how to contribute, please open an Issue on GitHub and ask. We are happy to guide you through your first contribution!

1. Problem-Solving Patterns: Sliding Window
  2. Problem-Solving Patterns: Two Pointers
  3. Problem-Solving Patterns: Backtracking
  4. Problem-Solving Patterns: Hashing
  5. Problem-Solving Patterns: Bit Manipulation
  6. Common Coding Interview Problems

docs.title: End-of-Volume Project
docs.text:
1. Capstone Project: Build an Algorithmic Challenge Toolkit:
  2. Implement a set of classic algorithms and data structures
  3. Include CLI interface to run/search/test algorithms
  4. Apply to solve a real-world problem (e.g., shortest path finder, text search engine, or scheduling system)

docs.title: Part I - Foundations of Quantum Computing
docs.text:
1. What is Quantum Computing?
  2. Classical vs Quantum Computing
  3. Bits vs Qubits
  4. Quantum Superposition
  5. Quantum Entanglement
  6. Quantum Measurement
  7. Bra-Ket Notation (Dirac Notation)
  8. Quantum Gates: Introduction
  9. Common Quantum Gates (X, Y, Z, H, S, T)
  10. Multi-Qubit Gates (CNOT, Toffoli, SWAP)

docs.title: Part II - Quantum Programming with Python
docs.text:
1. Installing Qiskit
  2. Understanding the Qiskit Workflow
  3. Creating and Manipulating Qubits
  4. Applying Quantum Gates in Qiskit
  5. Measuring Qubits in Qiskit
  6. Visualizing Circuits
  7. Running Circuits on a Simulator
  8. Running Circuits on Real Quantum Hardware (IBM Quantum)

docs.title: Part III - Quantum Algorithms
docs.text:
1. Introduction to Quantum Algorithms
  2. The Deutsch-Jozsa Algorithm
  3. Grover’s Algorithm
  4. Shor’s Algorithm (Conceptual Overview + Small Demo)
  5. Quantum Fourier Transform (QFT)
  6. Variational Quantum Algorithms (VQE, QAOA Overview)
  7. Quantum Machine Learning (Intro)

docs.title: Part IV - Quantum Data and Error Handling
docs.text:
1. Quantum Registers and Classical Registers
  2. Quantum Error and Noise
  3. Error Mitigation in Qiskit
  4. Quantum State Tomography
  5. Limitations of Current Quantum Hardware

docs.title: Part V - Applications of Quantum Computing
docs.text:
1. Quantum Cryptography (Conceptual + Python Demos)
  2. Quantum Search Applications
  3. Optimization with Quantum Algorithms
  4. Quantum Simulation for Physics and Chemistry
  5. Quantum Machine Learning Applications

docs.title: Part VI - Future of Quantum Computing
docs.text:
1. Current State of Quantum Technology
  2. Quantum Supremacy Debate
  3. Post-Quantum Cryptography
  4. Hybrid Quantum-Classical Algorithms
  5. The Future Roadmap of Quantum Python Development

docs.title: End-of-Volume Project
docs.text:
1. Capstone Project: Build a Quantum Simulation Project using Qiskit:
  2. Simulate qubits and gates
  3. Implement at least one quantum algorithm (e.g., Grover’s Search)
  4. Run on a real IBM Quantum backend (if available)
  5. Document results and compare simulation vs real quantum execution

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Windows does not come with Python preinstalled. To start programming, we must download, install, and configure the latest version of Python.

docs.title: 2. Downloading Python
docs.text:
1. Open a web browser.
  2. Go to the official Python download page: https://www.python.org/downloads/windows/
  3. The site will automatically suggest the latest stable version (for example: Python 3.12.x).
  4. Click the Download Python 3.x.x button.

docs.title: 3. Running the Installer
docs.text:
1. Locate the downloaded file in your Downloads folder (example: python-3.12.x-amd64.exe).
  2. Double-click the installer to run it.
  3. On the first screen:
  4. ✅ Check the box “Add Python to PATH” (very important).
  5. Click Install Now.
  6. Wait for the installation to complete.

docs.title: 4. Custom Installation (Optional)
docs.text: If you want more control: - Choose Customize installation. - Options you may enable: - Documentation - pip (package manager) - Add Python to environment variables - This is useful if you want multiple versions of Python installed.

docs.title: 5. Verifying Installation
docs.text:
1. Open the Command Prompt (press Win + R, type cmd, press Enter).
  2. Type: 
python --version

or 

py --version

You should see something like: 

Python 3.12.2
  1. Verify pip: 
pip --version

docs.title: 6. First Run of Python
docs.text:
In Command Prompt, type: 

python

This opens the Python REPL (interactive shell). Type exit() or press Ctrl + Z then Enter to quit.

docs.title: 7. Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• ‘python’ not recognized:
  • Try py instead.
  • If that works, it means Python is installed but not added to PATH.

  • Reinstall and check the “Add to PATH” option.

  • Multiple versions of Python:

  • Use py -0 to list installed versions.

  • Run a specific version with py -3.12 or py -3.11.

  • Pip missing:

  • Run the installer again and check pip option.

docs.title: 8. Uninstalling Python
docs.text:
1. Open Control Panel → Programs → Programs and Features.
  2. Find Python in the list.
  3. Select it and click Uninstall.

docs.title: 9. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ Python is now installed on Windows. In the next chapter, we will learn how to install Python on macOS.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: macOS includes a system version of Python, but it is often outdated and should not be used for development. It is recommended to install the latest stable Python release separately.

docs.title: 2. Checking the Current Python Version
docs.text:
Open Terminal (press Cmd + Space, type Terminal, press Enter) and run: 

python3 --version

If the version is older than 3.10 or missing, install the latest release. You can also check if pip is available: 

pip3 --version

docs.title: 3. Downloading the Official Installer
docs.text:
1. Open a web browser.
  2. Visit the official download page: https://www.python.org/downloads/macos/
  3. The site will suggest the latest stable version (e.g., Python 3.12.x).
  4. Download the macOS 64-bit universal installer (.pkg file).

docs.title: 4. Installing with the .pkg Installer
docs.text:
1. Locate the downloaded file in Downloads (example: python-3.12.x-macosx10.9.pkg).
  2. Double-click the .pkg file.
  3. Follow the prompts:
  4. Continue → Agree to license → Select install location.
  5. Enter your administrator password when asked.
  6. After installation, Python is usually placed in /usr/local/bin/python3.

docs.title: 5. Alternative: Installing with Homebrew
docs.text:
If you prefer the Homebrew package manager:

  1. Install Homebrew (if not already installed): 
/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"
  1. Install Python: 
brew install python
  1. Verify installation: 
python3 --version
pip3 --version

docs.title: 6. Verifying Installation
docs.text:
Check that Python and pip are working: 

python3 --version
pip3 --version

Expected output: 

Python 3.12.2
pip 23.x.x

docs.title: 7. Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• Command not found: Restart Terminal or confirm the path with: 
which python3
  • Multiple versions of Python:
  • macOS may have an old system Python.

  • Always use python3 instead of python.

  • pip missing: Install separately with: 

sudo apt install python3-pip   # if on Linux subsystem
brew reinstall python          # if using Homebrew
  • PATH issues: Add /usr/local/bin to your PATH if needed by editing ~/.zshrc or ~/.bashrc.

docs.title: 8. Uninstalling Python
docs.text:
• If installed via the .pkg file, manually remove from /Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/.
  • If installed with Homebrew, run: 
brew uninstall python

docs.title: 9. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ Python is now installed on macOS. In the next chapter, we will install Python on Linux distributions.

docs.title: Chapter 3: Installing Python on Linux (Ubuntu, Fedora, Arch)
1. Introduction
docs.text: Most Linux distributions come with Python preinstalled, but the system version is often outdated. For development work, it is recommended to install the latest stable Python release using your distribution’s package manager.

docs.title: 2. Checking the Current Python Version
docs.text:
Before installing, check what version of Python is already on your system: 

python3 --version

If you see Python 3.10 or newer, you may already be fine. If the command fails or the version is older, follow the steps below.

You can also check pip (Python’s package manager): 

pip3 --version

If pip is missing, it will need to be installed.

docs.title: 3. Installing on Ubuntu and Debian
docs.text:
Update package lists: 

sudo apt update

Install Python 3 and pip: 

sudo apt install python3 python3-pip -y

Verify installation: 

python3 --version
pip3 --version

To uninstall (if you need to remove a broken version): 

sudo apt remove python3 python3-pip

docs.title: 4. Installing on Fedora
docs.text:
Update packages: 

sudo dnf update -y

Install Python 3 and pip: 

sudo dnf install python3 python3-pip -y

Verify installation: 

python3 --version
pip3 --version

Uninstall if needed: 

sudo dnf remove python3 python3-pip

docs.title: 5. Installing on Arch Linux
docs.text:
Update the system: 

sudo pacman -Syu

Install Python and pip: 

sudo pacman -S python python-pip

Verify installation: 

python --version
pip --version

Uninstall if needed: 

sudo pacman -R python python-pip

docs.title: 6. Building from Source (Advanced Users)
docs.text:
If you want the very latest Python release:

  1. Download the source from https://www.python.org/ftp/python/.
  2. Extract and compile: 
tar -xf Python-3.x.x.tgz
cd Python-3.x.x
./configure --enable-optimizations
make
sudo make install
  1. Verify installation: 
python3 --version

docs.title: 7. Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• Command not found: Try python3 instead of python, or check your PATH with: 
which python3
  • pip missing: Install separately if not included: 
sudo apt install python3-pip -y     # Ubuntu/Debian
sudo dnf install python3-pip -y     # Fedora
sudo pacman -S python-pip           # Arch
  • Multiple versions installed: Use update-alternatives (Debian/Ubuntu) to switch default versions.

docs.title: 8. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ Python is now installed and ready on your Linux system. In the next chapter, we will set up IDLE, Python’s built-in editor, to start writing your first programs.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: IDLE (Integrated Development and Learning Environment) is Python’s simple built-in editor. It is included with most Python installations and is a great starting point for beginners.

docs.title: 2. Checking if IDLE is Installed
docs.text:
Open a terminal (macOS/Linux) or Command Prompt (Windows) and type:

idle3
  • If IDLE opens, you are ready to use it.
  • If the command is not found, install it using your package manager.

docs.title: 3. Installing IDLE on Windows
docs.text:
• IDLE is automatically installed when you install Python from python.org.
  • If you unchecked IDLE during installation, run the installer again and enable the tcl/tk and IDLE option.

docs.title: 4. Installing IDLE on macOS
docs.text:
• If you installed Python using the official .pkg installer, IDLE is already included.
  • If using Homebrew, install IDLE with: 
brew install python-tk

docs.title: 5. Installing IDLE on Linux
docs.text:
For Ubuntu/Debian:

sudo apt update
sudo apt install idle3 -y

For Fedora:

sudo dnf install python3-tools -y

For Arch:

sudo pacman -S tk

docs.title: 6. Starting IDLE
docs.text:
• On Windows: search for IDLE in the Start Menu.
  • On macOS/Linux: run idle3 from Terminal.

When IDLE opens, you will see the Python Shell (interactive REPL).

docs.title: 7. Running Your First Program
docs.text:
1. In IDLE, go to File → New File.
  2. Type this program:
print("Hello, Python from IDLE!")
  1. Save the file as hello.py.
  2. Press F5 or choose Run → Run Module.
  3. You should see the output in the Python Shell window:
Hello, Python from IDLE!

docs.title: 8. Customizing IDLE
docs.text:
• Fonts and Colors: Go to Options → Configure IDLE.
  • Themes: Switch to dark mode or change syntax colors.
  • Indentation: Adjust spaces per tab for coding style.

docs.title: 9. Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• IDLE not opening: Ensure tkinter is installed. On Ubuntu/Debian:

bash sudo apt install python3-tk -y

  • Multiple Python versions: If IDLE opens the wrong version, check the shebang in the IDLE launcher or use the full command: 
idle3.12

docs.title: 10. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now have IDLE set up and running. In the next chapter, we will set up VS Code, a more powerful editor for Python development.

docs.title: Chapter 5: Installing and Configuring VS Code
1. Introduction
docs.text: Visual Studio Code (VS Code) is a lightweight but powerful code editor from Microsoft. It is widely used for Python development because of its excellent extensions, debugging tools, and integrated terminal.

docs.title: 2. Downloading VS Code
docs.text:
1. Open your web browser.
  2. Go to the official download page: https://code.visualstudio.com/
  3. Choose your operating system (Windows, macOS, or Linux).
  4. Download the installer (.exe, .dmg, or .deb/.rpm).

docs.title: 3. Installing on Windows
docs.text:
1. Run the downloaded .exe installer.
  2. Accept the license agreement.
  3. Choose installation location (default is fine).
  4. On the "Select Additional Tasks" screen, check:
  5. ✅ Add to PATH
  6. ✅ Register as default editor for supported file types
  7. ✅ Add "Open with Code" to context menu
  8. Click Install.

docs.title: 4. Installing on macOS
docs.text:
1. Open the downloaded .dmg file.
  2. Drag Visual Studio Code.app into the Applications folder.
  3. Open VS Code from Launchpad or Spotlight.
  4. (Optional) Add code command to PATH:
  5. Open VS Code.
  6. Press Cmd + Shift + P, type Shell Command: Install 'code' command in PATH, and press Enter.

docs.title: 5. Installing on Linux
docs.text:
For Ubuntu/Debian: 

sudo apt update
sudo apt install ./code_*_amd64.deb

For Fedora/RHEL: 

sudo dnf install ./code-*.rpm

For Arch (via AUR): 

yay -S visual-studio-code-bin

docs.title: 6. Installing the Python Extension
docs.text:
1. Open VS Code.
  2. Go to the Extensions view (Ctrl + Shift + X or Cmd + Shift + X on macOS).
  3. Search for Python.
  4. Install the official Microsoft Python extension.

docs.title: 7. Configuring Python in VS Code
docs.text:
1. Open any .py file or create a new one.
  2. If prompted, select your Python interpreter.
  3. You can also manually set it:
  4. Open the Command Palette (Ctrl + Shift + P).
  5. Type Python: Select Interpreter.
  6. Choose the version you installed earlier.

docs.title: 8. Running Your First Program
docs.text:
1. Create a new file hello.py.
  2. Type: 
print("Hello from VS Code!")
  1. Save the file.
  2. Right-click inside the editor and select Run Python File in Terminal.
  3. You should see the output in the integrated terminal:
Hello from VS Code!

docs.title: 9. Customizing VS Code
docs.text:
• Themes: Install new themes from Extensions marketplace.
  • Fonts: Go to Settings → Font Family.
  • Keybindings: Customize shortcuts via Keyboard Shortcuts (Ctrl + K Ctrl + S).
  • Extensions: Explore other useful extensions (Pylance, Jupyter, GitLens).

docs.title: 10. Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• Python not detected: Check that Python is installed and added to PATH.
  • Multiple Python versions: Ensure the correct interpreter is selected via Python: Select Interpreter.
  • Code command not found (macOS/Linux): Reinstall the code shell command from Command Palette.

docs.title: 11. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now have VS Code installed and configured with Python. In the next chapter, we will set up PyCharm, another popular IDE for Python.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text:
PyCharm is a popular Integrated Development Environment (IDE) created by JetBrains. It comes in two editions: - Community Edition (free, open-source) → ideal for beginners. - Professional Edition (paid) → adds advanced features such as web development and database tools.

For most learners, the Community Edition is sufficient.

docs.title: 2. Downloading PyCharm
docs.text:
1. Open your web browser.
  2. Go to the official PyCharm download page: https://www.jetbrains.com/pycharm/download/
  3. Choose your operating system (Windows, macOS, Linux).
  4. Download the Community Edition installer.

docs.title: 3. Installing on Windows
docs.text:
1. Run the .exe installer.
  2. Follow the setup wizard:
  3. Choose installation location.
  4. (Optional) Create a desktop shortcut.
  5. ✅ Check Add "Open Folder as Project" option.
  6. ✅ Add to PATH (recommended).
  7. Click Install and wait for the installation to finish.
  8. Launch PyCharm from the Start Menu.

docs.title: 4. Installing on macOS
docs.text:
1. Open the .dmg file you downloaded.
  2. Drag PyCharm CE.app into the Applications folder.
  3. Open it via Spotlight or Launchpad.
  4. (Optional) Add charm command to PATH for opening projects from Terminal:
  5. Open PyCharm.
  6. Go to Tools → Create Command-line Launcher.
  7. Accept default settings.

docs.title: 5. Installing on Linux
docs.text:
For Ubuntu/Debian: 

sudo snap install pycharm-community --classic

For Fedora/RHEL (if Snap not available, use tarball): 

sudo tar -xzf pycharm-community-*.tar.gz -C /opt/
cd /opt/pycharm-community-*/
bin/pycharm.sh

For Arch: 

yay -S pycharm-community-edition

docs.title: 6. Initial Setup
docs.text:
1. Start PyCharm for the first time.
  2. Choose a theme (Light or Dark).
  3. (Optional) Import settings if you used PyCharm before.
  4. Configure font size and keymap if desired.

docs.title: 7. Configuring Python Interpreter
docs.text:
1. Create a new project or open an existing folder.
  2. PyCharm will prompt you to set a Python interpreter.
  3. Choose one of the following:
  4. Existing interpreter → Use the system Python you installed earlier.
  5. Virtual environment → PyCharm can create one for your project.
  6. Confirm the interpreter path (e.g., python3.12).

docs.title: 8. Creating Your First Project
docs.text:
1. From the welcome screen, click New Project.
  2. Enter a project name (e.g., HelloPython).
  3. Choose the interpreter.
  4. Click Create.
  5. Inside the project, create a new Python file:
  6. Right-click project folder → New → Python File.
  7. Name it hello.py.
  8. Type: 
print("Hello from PyCharm!")
  1. Right-click the file and choose Run 'hello'.
  2. The output will appear in the Run window: 
Hello from PyCharm!

docs.title: 9. Customizing PyCharm
docs.text:
• Themes and Fonts: Settings → Appearance & Behavior → Appearance.
  • Keymaps: Choose from IntelliJ, VS Code, or custom keybindings.
  • Plugins: Explore useful plugins (e.g., Markdown support, Git tools, database tools).

docs.title: 10. Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• Interpreter not found: Double-check Python is installed and added to PATH.
  • PyCharm feels slow: Increase memory in Help → Change Memory Settings.
  • Projects not opening: Try deleting .idea folder in project directory and reopen.

docs.title: 11. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now have PyCharm installed and configured. In the next chapter, we will set up Jupyter Notebook, an interactive environment widely used in data science.

docs.title: Chapter 7: Installing and Configuring Jupyter Notebook
1. Introduction
docs.text: Jupyter Notebook is an interactive coding environment widely used in data science, machine learning, and education. It allows you to write and run Python code in small cells, mix code with text, and create rich documents with charts and equations.

docs.title: 2. Installing Jupyter with pip
docs.text:
If you already have Python and pip installed, you can install Jupyter directly:

pip install notebook

Verify installation:

jupyter --version

docs.title: 3. Installing Jupyter with Anaconda
docs.text:
If you installed Anaconda (Chapter 8), Jupyter comes preinstalled. You can update it with:

conda install jupyter

docs.title: 4. Starting Jupyter Notebook
docs.text:
1. Open a terminal (Linux/macOS) or Command Prompt (Windows).
  2. Type:
jupyter notebook
  1. This will start a local server and open your default browser. The default address is: http://localhost:8888

docs.title: 5. Creating Your First Notebook
docs.text:
1. In the browser interface, click New → Python 3 (ipykernel).
  2. A blank notebook will open.
  3. In the first cell, type:
print("Hello, Jupyter!")
  1. Press Shift + Enter to run the cell.
  2. You should see the output below the cell:
Hello, Jupyter!

docs.title: 6. Using Markdown in Jupyter
docs.text:
You can add formatted text to your notebooks: 1. Change a cell type to Markdown. 2. Enter text like:

# This is a heading
- Bullet point
- **Bold text**
  1. Run the cell with Shift + Enter.

docs.title: 7. Useful Keyboard Shortcuts
docs.text:
• Shift + Enter → Run current cell.
  • A → Insert cell above.
  • B → Insert cell below.
  • M → Change cell to Markdown.
  • Y → Change cell to Code.
  • Ctrl + S → Save notebook.

docs.title: 8. Customizing Jupyter Notebook
docs.text:
• Change the working directory by launching Jupyter from the desired folder.
  • Install themes with pip install jupyterthemes.
  • Example:
jt -t monokai

docs.title: 9. Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• Jupyter not found: Make sure Python Scripts folder is in PATH (~/.local/bin on Linux/macOS, C:\Users\<name>\AppData\Roaming\Python\Python312\Scripts on Windows).
  • Port already in use: Start with a different port:
jupyter notebook --port 8889
  • Browser not opening: Copy the URL with token from the terminal and paste it manually into a browser.

docs.title: 10. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ Jupyter Notebook is now installed and running. In the next chapter, we will install and configure Anaconda, which includes Jupyter and many other useful data science tools.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Anaconda is a Python distribution widely used for data science, machine learning, and scientific computing. It comes bundled with Python, Jupyter Notebook, and many popular libraries (NumPy, Pandas, Matplotlib). Using Anaconda makes it easier to manage packages and environments.

docs.title: 2. Downloading Anaconda
docs.text:
1. Open your web browser.
  2. Go to the official download page: https://www.anaconda.com/download
  3. Choose the correct installer for your operating system (Windows, macOS, Linux).
  4. Select the latest Python 3.x version.

docs.title: 3. Installing on Windows
docs.text:
1. Run the downloaded .exe installer.
  2. Follow the setup wizard:
  3. Accept the license.
  4. Choose Install for Just Me (recommended).
  5. Keep the default install location.
  6. ✅ Check Add Anaconda to PATH (or let the installer manage PATH).
  7. Click Install and wait.
  8. After installation, open Anaconda Navigator from the Start Menu.

docs.title: 4. Installing on macOS
docs.text:
1. Open the .pkg installer you downloaded.
  2. Follow the installation prompts.
  3. Alternatively, use Homebrew: 
brew install --cask anaconda
  1. After installation, initialize conda:
conda init zsh

(If you use Bash: conda init bash)

  1. Restart Terminal.

docs.title: 5. Installing on Linux
docs.text:
1. Download the .sh installer from the Anaconda website.
  2. Open Terminal and navigate to the Downloads folder.
  3. Run the installer: 
bash Anaconda3-2023.x-Linux-x86_64.sh
  1. Follow the prompts:
  2. Press Enter to scroll through the license.
  3. Type yes to accept.
  4. Choose installation directory (default is fine).
  5. Initialize conda: 
source ~/anaconda3/bin/activate
conda init
  1. Restart your shell.

docs.title: 6. Verifying Installation
docs.text:
Check conda version: 

conda --version

Check Python version inside conda: 

python --version

docs.title: 7. Updating Anaconda
docs.text:
Keep Anaconda up to date: 

conda update conda
conda update anaconda

docs.title: 8. Creating and Managing Environments
docs.text:
Create a new environment with Python 3.12: 

conda create -n myenv python=3.12

Activate it: 

conda activate myenv

Deactivate: 

conda deactivate

Remove environment: 

conda remove -n myenv --all

docs.title: 9. Using Anaconda Navigator
docs.text:
• Navigator is a graphical tool included with Anaconda.
  • It lets you:
  • Launch Jupyter Notebook.
  • Install and update packages.
  • Manage environments visually.

Launch it from Start Menu (Windows), Launchpad (macOS), or type: 

anaconda-navigator

docs.title: 10. Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• conda command not found: Restart your terminal, or add Anaconda to PATH manually.
  • Slow package installs: Use conda-forge channel: 
conda install -c conda-forge <package-name>
  • Conflicts during updates: Create a fresh environment instead of upgrading the base environment.

docs.title: 11. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ Anaconda is now installed and configured. In the next chapter, we will explore other IDEs and editors you can use for Python development.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Python can be written in many different editors and IDEs (Integrated Development Environments). We’ve already covered IDLE, VS Code, PyCharm, and Jupyter Notebook. In this chapter, we’ll look at some other popular options you may encounter.

docs.title: 2. Thonny
docs.text:
• A beginner-friendly Python IDE.
  • Comes preinstalled with Python on Raspberry Pi.
  • Features:
  • Simple interface.
  • Built-in debugger.
  • Great for first-time programmers.
  • Installation: 
sudo apt install thonny    # Ubuntu/Debian
brew install thonny        # macOS (via Homebrew)

docs.title: 3. Spyder
docs.text:
• A scientific Python IDE included in Anaconda.
  • Features:
  • Variable explorer (see your data in tables).
  • Built-in IPython console.
  • Integrated with scientific libraries (NumPy, Pandas, Matplotlib).
  • Launch with: 
spyder

docs.title: 4. Sublime Text
docs.text:
• A fast, lightweight text editor.
  • Features:
  • Powerful search and multi-cursor editing.
  • Many Python plugins available.
  • Installation:
  • Download from https://www.sublimetext.com/.

docs.title: 5. Atom (Deprecated but still used)
docs.text:
• A hackable text editor built by GitHub.
  • Although officially discontinued in 2022, some developers still use forks.
  • Features:
  • Easy customization.
  • Good Python plugins.

docs.title: 6. Eclipse + PyDev
docs.text:
• Eclipse is a Java IDE, but with the PyDev plugin, it can be used for Python.
  • Features:
  • Code completion.
  • Debugging.
  • Refactoring tools.
  • Installation:
  • Install Eclipse from https://www.eclipse.org/.
  • Add PyDev plugin from Eclipse Marketplace.

docs.title: 7. Vim and NeoVim
docs.text:
• Terminal-based editors, powerful once mastered.
  • Popular among advanced developers.
  • Features:
  • Highly customizable.
  • Plugins like coc.nvim or YouCompleteMe add Python support.
  • Installation: 
sudo apt install vim

For NeoVim: 

sudo apt install neovim

docs.title: 8. Emacs
docs.text:
• Another advanced, highly customizable editor.
  • Python support with plugins like elpy.
  • Installation: 
sudo apt install emacs

docs.title: 9. Which Editor Should You Use?
docs.text:
• Beginners → Thonny, IDLE, or VS Code.
  • Data Science → Jupyter, Spyder.
  • Professional Development → PyCharm, VS Code.
  • Power Users → Vim/NeoVim, Emacs.

docs.title: 10. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ Now you know the wide variety of Python IDEs and editors available. In the next chapter, we’ll dive into using the Python REPL (Read-Eval-Print Loop).

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: The Python REPL (Read-Eval-Print Loop) is an interactive shell where you can type Python commands and see results immediately. It is one of the fastest ways to experiment, test small pieces of code, and learn Python.

docs.title: 2. Starting the REPL
docs.text:
Open a terminal (Linux/macOS) or Command Prompt (Windows) and type:

python

or, if multiple versions are installed:

python3

You should see something like:

Python 3.12.2 (tags/v3.12.2:...) 
>>>

The >>> prompt means Python is ready for input.

docs.title: 3. Running Basic Commands
docs.text:
Try typing:

2 + 3

Output:

5

Try another:

print("Hello, Python!")

Output:

Hello, Python!

docs.title: 4. Using Variables
docs.text:
You can create variables and use them immediately:

x = 10
y = 5
x + y

Output:

15

docs.title: 5. Using Built-in Functions
docs.text:
The REPL supports all Python functions:

len("Python")

Output:

6

docs.title: 6. Getting Help
docs.text:
Inside the REPL, type:

help()

This opens an interactive help system. Type quit to exit help.

You can also get help on a specific function:

help(len)

docs.title: 7. Exiting the REPL
docs.text:
To exit, type:

exit()

or press:

  • Ctrl + Z then Enter (Windows)
  • Ctrl + D (Linux/macOS)

docs.title: 8. Useful Tips
docs.text:
• Use the arrow keys to scroll through command history.
  • Press Tab to autocomplete variable names and functions.
  • Use Ctrl + L (Linux/macOS) or cls command on Windows to clear the screen.

docs.title: 9. Why Use the REPL?
docs.text:
• Great for learning Python.
  • Quick way to test ideas.
  • Lightweight compared to opening an IDE.

docs.title: 10. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know how to use the Python REPL to run code interactively. In the next chapter, we’ll learn how to run Python scripts from the command line.

docs.title: Chapter 11: Running Python Scripts from the Command Line
1. Introduction
docs.text: While the Python REPL is great for quick experiments, real projects require saving code into files. You can then run these Python scripts from the command line.

docs.title: 2. Creating Your First Python Script
docs.text:
1. Open any text editor (Notepad, VS Code, PyCharm, etc.).
  2. Type the following code:
print("Hello from a Python script!")
  1. Save the file as hello.py.

docs.title: 3. Running on Windows
docs.text:
1. Open Command Prompt.
  2. Navigate to the folder where you saved hello.py. Example:
cd C:\Users\YourName\Documents
  1. Run the script with:
python hello.py

If you have multiple versions of Python, use:

py hello.py

docs.title: 4. Running on macOS/Linux
docs.text:
1. Open Terminal.
  2. Navigate to the folder where you saved hello.py. Example:
cd ~/Documents
  1. Run the script with:
python3 hello.py

docs.title: 5. Using Absolute and Relative Paths
docs.text:
You don’t always need to cd into the directory. You can run a script by giving its path: 

python3 ~/Documents/hello.py

Or from the current folder: 

python3 ./hello.py

docs.title: 6. Adding a Shebang (Linux/macOS only)
docs.text:
At the top of your script, add:

#!/usr/bin/env python3

Make the file executable:

chmod +x hello.py

Now you can run it directly:

./hello.py

docs.title: 7. Passing Arguments to a Script
docs.text:
You can pass values to your script:

python3 hello.py world

In your script:

import sys
print("Hello,", sys.argv[1])

Output:

Hello, world

docs.title: 8. Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• ‘python’ not recognized (Windows) → Use py or check that Python was added to PATH during installation.
  • Permission denied (Linux/macOS) → Use chmod +x filename.py to make it executable.
  • Wrong version running → Specify python3 instead of python.

docs.title: 9. Why Run Scripts from the Command Line?
docs.text:
• Reproducible: you can save and run the same script multiple times.
  • Shareable: scripts can be distributed to others.
  • Practical: most real-world Python projects are run as scripts or applications.

docs.title: 10. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know how to run Python scripts from the command line. In the next chapter, we will explore how to use Python with different text editors.

docs.title: Chapter 12: Using Python with Different Text Editors
1. Introduction
docs.text: Python code can be written in any plain text editor. While IDEs like VS Code and PyCharm are powerful, sometimes a simple text editor is faster and more lightweight. In this chapter, we’ll explore using Python with several popular text editors.

docs.title: 2. Notepad (Windows)
docs.text:
• The simplest editor available on Windows.
  • Steps:
  • Open Notepad.

  • Write a Python program, for example:

    python print("Hello from Notepad!") 3. Save the file with the .py extension (e.g., hello.py). - Select Save as type → All Files. - Encoding: UTF-8. 4. Run the file from Command Prompt with:

    bash python hello.py

docs.title: 3. TextEdit (macOS)
docs.text:
• The built-in text editor for macOS.
  • Steps:
  • Open TextEdit.
  • Go to Format → Make Plain Text.
  • Write Python code and save it with .py extension (e.g., hello.py).

  • Run from Terminal with:

    bash python3 hello.py

docs.title: 4. Nano (Linux/macOS Terminal Editor)
docs.text:
• A simple terminal-based text editor.
  • Steps:
  • Open Terminal.

  • Create a new file with:

    bash nano hello.py 3. Write Python code inside. 4. Save with Ctrl + O, exit with Ctrl + X. 5. Run with:

    bash python3 hello.py

docs.title: 5. Vim and Neovim
docs.text:
• Powerful modal text editors for advanced users.
  • Steps:

  • Install Vim:

    bash sudo apt install vim # Ubuntu/Debian sudo pacman -S vim # Arch brew install vim # macOS

  • Create a Python file:

    bash vim hello.py

  • Press i to enter insert mode, write Python code.

  • Save and quit: Esc → :wq.

  • Run as usual:

    bash python3 hello.py

docs.title: 6. Sublime Text
docs.text:
• A fast, extensible editor with Python plugins.
  • Installation: https://www.sublimetext.com/
  • Steps:
  • Open Sublime Text.
  • Write Python code.
  • Save with .py extension.
  • Install the SublimeREPL plugin for running Python inside Sublime.

docs.title: 7. Atom (Discontinued, still usable via forks)
docs.text:
• Atom was discontinued, but forks like Pulsar exist.
  • Features include extensions and integrated terminals.

docs.title: 8. Why Use Text Editors?
docs.text:
• Lightweight compared to IDEs.
  • Universal — works on any OS.
  • Customizable — plugins, syntax highlighting, linting.

docs.title: 9. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know how to write Python code in various text editors. In the next chapter, we’ll look at the difference between Python scripts and modules.

docs.title: Chapter 13: Understanding Python Scripts vs Modules
1. Introduction
docs.text: In Python, you will often hear the terms script and module. They are both Python files, but they serve slightly different purposes. Understanding this difference is important when you start organizing larger projects.

docs.title: 2. What is a Script?
docs.text:
• A script is a Python file meant to be run directly.
  • It usually performs a specific task when executed.
  • Example: hello.py 
print("Hello, this is a script!")

Run it from the command line:

python3 hello.py

Output:

Hello, this is a script!

docs.title: 3. What is a Module?
docs.text:
• A module is a Python file that provides functions, classes, or variables for other Python files to use.
  • Instead of running it directly, you import it.

Example: mymath.py

def add(a, b):
    return a + b

Use it in another file test.py:

import mymath
print(mymath.add(2, 3))

Output:

5

docs.title: 4. Using __name__ == "__main__"
docs.text:
Sometimes a file can act as both a script and a module. This is done using the special variable __name__.

Example: dual.py

def greet(name):
    print("Hello,", name)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    # This runs only if the file is executed directly
    greet("World")
  • Run directly: 
python3 dual.py

Output: 

Hello, World
  • Import as module:
import dual
dual.greet("Alice")

Output: 

Hello, Alice

docs.title: 5. Built-in Modules
docs.text:
Python comes with many built-in modules. Example:

import math
print(math.sqrt(16))

Output:

4.0

docs.title: 6. Creating Your Own Modules
docs.text:
• Any .py file can be a module.
  • Keep related functions together in one file.
  • Example: geometry.py for shapes, strings.py for text utilities.
  • You can import them into any script in the same directory.

docs.title: 7. Why the Distinction Matters
docs.text:
• Scripts → run tasks.
  • Modules → provide reusable code.
  • Understanding this distinction helps organize code into projects with many files.

docs.title: 8. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand the difference between Python scripts and modules. In the next chapter, we’ll cover debugging basics to help you fix errors in your programs.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Debugging is the process of finding and fixing errors (bugs) in your code. Every programmer encounters bugs — they are a normal part of coding. In this chapter, we’ll learn some basic debugging techniques in Python.

docs.title: 2. Types of Errors
docs.text:
1. Syntax Errors → Mistakes in code structure. Example:

python print("Hello"

Output:

SyntaxError: unexpected EOF while parsing

  1. Runtime Errors → Errors that occur while the program is running. Example:

python x = 10 / 0

Output:

ZeroDivisionError: division by zero

  1. Logic Errors → Code runs but produces the wrong result. Example:

python def add(a, b): return a - b # Bug: should be +

docs.title: 3. Using Print Statements
docs.text:
The simplest debugging method: insert print() statements.

Example:

x = 5
y = 0
print("Before division:", x, y)
z = x / y

Output shows the values before the crash.

docs.title: 4. Using the Built-in pdb Debugger
docs.text:
Python includes a command-line debugger called pdb.

Run your script with:

python3 -m pdb script.py

Commands inside pdb: - n → next line - s → step into function - c → continue execution - p variable → print variable value - q → quit debugger

docs.title: 5. Debugging in IDLE
docs.text:
• Open your script in IDLE.
  • Go to Debug → Debugger.
  • This opens a panel where you can step through code and inspect variables.

docs.title: 6. Debugging in VS Code
docs.text:
1. Open your script in VS Code.
  2. Click in the margin next to a line to add a breakpoint.
  3. Press F5 or go to Run → Start Debugging.
  4. The program will pause at the breakpoint.
  5. Inspect variable values in the Debug Console.

docs.title: 7. Debugging in PyCharm
docs.text:
1. Open your script in PyCharm.
  2. Right-click and choose Debug instead of Run.
  3. Use breakpoints (red dots) to pause execution.
  4. Step through code with the toolbar (Step Over, Step Into).

docs.title: 8. Common Debugging Tips
docs.text:
• Read error messages carefully — they tell you the file, line, and type of error.
  • Start by fixing the first error in the traceback.
  • Use small test cases to isolate problems.
  • Don’t be afraid of bugs — they are opportunities to learn.

docs.title: 9. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know the basics of debugging in Python. In the next chapter, we’ll learn about pip, Python’s package manager, which lets you install and use external libraries.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: pip is Python’s default package manager. It allows you to install, update, and remove external libraries (packages) that extend Python’s functionality. Most Python projects use pip to manage dependencies.

docs.title: 2. Checking if pip is Installed
docs.text:
Open a terminal or Command Prompt and run:

pip --version

or

pip3 --version

You should see something like:

pip 23.2.1 from /usr/local/lib/python3.12/site-packages/pip (python 3.12)

If you get an error, pip may not be installed.

docs.title: 3. Installing pip (if missing)
docs.text:
• On Windows, reinstall Python with the pip option checked.
  • On Linux/macOS, install with: 
sudo apt install python3-pip        # Ubuntu/Debian
sudo dnf install python3-pip        # Fedora
brew install pipx && pipx ensurepath # macOS with Homebrew

docs.title: 4. Installing a Package
docs.text:
To install a package:

pip install requests

This installs the requests library for making HTTP requests.

docs.title: 5. Using Installed Packages
docs.text:
After installation, you can import the package in Python:

import requests
response = requests.get("https://example.com")
print(response.status_code)

docs.title: 6. Listing Installed Packages
docs.text:
Check what’s installed:

pip list

Sample output:

numpy  1.26.0
pandas 2.1.1
requests 2.31.0

docs.title: 7. Upgrading Packages
docs.text:
Update a package to the latest version:

pip install --upgrade requests

Upgrade pip itself:

pip install --upgrade pip

docs.title: 8. Uninstalling Packages
docs.text:
Remove a package:

pip uninstall requests

docs.title: 9. Requirements Files
docs.text:
For larger projects, dependencies are stored in a file called requirements.txt.

  • Create one:
pip freeze > requirements.txt
  • Install all packages from it:
pip install -r requirements.txt

docs.title: 10. Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• Permission denied (Linux/macOS) → Use pip install --user <package>.
  • pip installs wrong version → Make sure you use pip3 with Python 3.
  • PATH issues → Add the Python Scripts/ folder to PATH.

docs.title: 11. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know how to install and manage packages with pip. In the next chapter, we’ll explore virtual environments, which let you manage project-specific dependencies.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text:
A virtual environment is an isolated Python workspace. It lets you install packages for one project without affecting other projects or the system Python installation.

This is especially useful when: - Different projects require different package versions. - You want to avoid breaking system-installed Python packages.

docs.title: 2. Checking if venv is Installed
docs.text:
Python 3.3+ includes the venv module by default. Check by running:

python3 -m venv --help

If you see usage instructions, it’s available.

docs.title: 3. Creating a Virtual Environment
docs.text:
Navigate to your project folder and run:

python3 -m venv myenv

This creates a folder called myenv that contains a local Python installation.

docs.title: 4. Activating the Virtual Environment
docs.text:
• On Windows (Command Prompt):
myenv\Scripts\activate
  • On PowerShell:
.\myenv\Scripts\Activate.ps1
  • On Linux/macOS:
source myenv/bin/activate

When active, your shell prompt will show (myenv).

docs.title: 5. Installing Packages Inside the Virtual Environment
docs.text:
Once activated, any pip commands only affect the environment:

pip install requests

Check installed packages:

pip list

docs.title: 6. Deactivating the Environment
docs.text:
To leave the virtual environment, simply run:

deactivate

docs.title: 7. Removing a Virtual Environment
docs.text:
Since it’s just a folder, you can delete it safely:

rm -rf myenv   # Linux/macOS
rmdir /S myenv # Windows

docs.title: 8. Why Use Virtual Environments?
docs.text:
• Prevents dependency conflicts between projects.
  • Keeps your global Python installation clean.
  • Required in most professional Python projects.

docs.title: 9. Alternatives
docs.text:
• virtualenv: An older tool with extra features.
  • conda environments: Used with Anaconda for data science projects.
  • pipenv or poetry: Modern tools that combine dependency and environment management.

docs.title: 10. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know how to create and use virtual environments. In the next chapter, we’ll start exploring Python’s core language basics, beginning with variables and assignment rules.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: A variable is a name that stores a value in memory. In Python, you don’t need to declare a variable type — Python figures it out automatically. This is called dynamic typing.

docs.title: 2. Creating Variables
docs.text:
Assign a value to a variable with the = operator:

x = 10
name = "Alice"
pi = 3.14

docs.title: 3. Variable Naming Rules
docs.text:
• Must start with a letter or underscore (_).
  • Can contain letters, numbers, and underscores.
  • Case-sensitive (Name and name are different).
  • Cannot be a Python keyword (if, while, class, etc.).

✅ Valid examples: 

user_name = "Bob"
age2 = 25
_price = 99.99

❌ Invalid examples: 

2cool = "nope"      # cannot start with a number
first-name = "Eve"  # hyphen not allowed
class = "Physics"   # reserved keyword

docs.title: 4. Reassigning Variables
docs.text:
You can change a variable’s value at any time:

x = 5
x = "hello"

Here, x first held a number, then a string.

docs.title: 5. Multiple Assignments
docs.text:
You can assign multiple variables at once:

a, b, c = 1, 2, 3

Or give multiple variables the same value:

x = y = z = 0

docs.title: 6. Constants in Python
docs.text:
Python does not have true constants, but by convention: - Use ALL_CAPS names for values that should not change. 

PI = 3.14159
MAX_USERS = 100

docs.title: 7. Checking Variable Type
docs.text:
Use the built-in type() function:

x = 42
print(type(x))   # <class 'int'>

docs.title: 8. Deleting Variables
docs.text:
You can delete a variable with del:

x = 10
del x

Trying to use x now will give an error.

docs.title: 9. Best Practices
docs.text:
• Use descriptive names (age instead of a).
  • Follow lowercase_with_underscores convention.
  • Avoid single-letter names except in loops (i, j).

docs.title: 10. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand how variables work and the rules for naming them. In the next chapter, we’ll explore Python’s basic data types.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Python has several built-in data types that form the foundation of the language. Understanding these is essential because you will use them in almost every program.

docs.title: 2. Numbers
docs.text:
Python has different types of numbers: - Integers (int) → whole numbers - Floating-point numbers (float) → decimal numbers - Complex numbers (complex) → numbers with real and imaginary parts

Examples:

a = 10        # int
b = 3.14      # float
c = 2 + 3j    # complex

Check their types:

print(type(a))  # <class 'int'>
print(type(b))  # <class 'float'>
print(type(c))  # <class 'complex'>

docs.title: 3. Strings
docs.text:
A string is text enclosed in quotes.

name = "Alice"
greeting = 'Hello, world!'

Strings can be joined:

first = "Py"
second = "thon"
print(first + second)  # Python

docs.title: 4. Booleans
docs.text:
A boolean is either True or False.

is_active = True
is_logged_in = False

Booleans often come from comparisons:

print(5 > 3)   # True
print(2 == 4)  # False

docs.title: 5. None
docs.text:
None is a special type representing the absence of a value.

result = None
print(result)  # None

docs.title: 6. Lists
docs.text:
A list is an ordered, changeable collection.

fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
print(fruits[0])  # apple

Lists can be modified:

fruits.append("orange")
print(fruits)  # ['apple', 'banana', 'cherry', 'orange']

docs.title: 7. Tuples
docs.text:
A tuple is an ordered, unchangeable collection.

point = (3, 4)
print(point[0])  # 3

docs.title: 8. Sets
docs.text:
A set is an unordered collection of unique items.

numbers = {1, 2, 3, 3}
print(numbers)  # {1, 2, 3}

docs.title: 9. Dictionaries
docs.text:
A dictionary stores data as key-value pairs.

person = {"name": "Alice", "age": 25}
print(person["name"])  # Alice

docs.title: 10. Dynamic Typing in Python
docs.text:
You can reassign a variable to a different type:

x = 10
print(type(x))  # int
x = "hello"
print(type(x))  # str

docs.title: 11. Checking Data Types
docs.text:
Use type() and isinstance():

x = 3.14
print(type(x))               # <class 'float'>
print(isinstance(x, float))  # True

docs.title: 12. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know Python’s basic data types: numbers, strings, booleans, None, lists, tuples, sets, and dictionaries. In the next chapter, we’ll learn about type conversion and casting.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text:
Sometimes you need to change a value from one type to another. For example, converting a string "123" into a number 123. This process is called type conversion or casting.

Python supports two types of conversions: - Implicit Conversion (Type Casting by Python) - Explicit Conversion (Manual Casting by the Programmer)

docs.title: 2. Implicit Type Conversion
docs.text:
Python automatically converts smaller data types to larger ones when needed.

Example:

x = 10        # int
y = 2.5       # float
z = x + y     # int + float
print(z)      # 12.5
print(type(z))  # <class 'float'>

Here, Python automatically converted x into a float.

docs.title: 3. Explicit Type Conversion
docs.text:
You can manually convert a value to another type using built-in functions.

  • Convert to integer: 
x = int("42")
print(x)        # 42
print(type(x))  # <class 'int'>
  • Convert to float: 
y = float("3.14")
print(y)        # 3.14
  • Convert to string: 
z = str(100)
print(z)        # "100"
print(type(z))  # <class 'str'>

docs.title: 4. Converting Between Data Types
docs.text:
• List to Tuple:
numbers = [1, 2, 3]
t = tuple(numbers)
print(t)  # (1, 2, 3)
  • Tuple to List:
t = (4, 5, 6)
lst = list(t)
print(lst)  # [4, 5, 6]
  • List to Set:
numbers = [1, 2, 2, 3]
s = set(numbers)
print(s)  # {1, 2, 3}
  • Dictionary Keys to List:
person = {"name": "Alice", "age": 25}
keys = list(person.keys())
print(keys)  # ['name', 'age']

docs.title: 5. Converting Booleans
docs.text:
Booleans (True or False) can also be converted. 

print(int(True))   # 1
print(int(False))  # 0
print(bool(0))     # False
print(bool(42))    # True
print(bool(""))    # False
print(bool("hi"))  # True

docs.title: 6. Common Pitfalls
docs.text:
• Converting non-numeric strings to numbers will fail: 
x = int("hello")  # ValueError
  • Floating-point to integer conversion truncates (does not round): 
print(int(3.99))  # 3

docs.title: 7. When to Use Conversion
docs.text:
• When reading user input (always a string by default).
  • When working with files or APIs that return text.
  • When preparing data for mathematical operations.

docs.title: 8. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand how to convert between Python data types. In the next chapter, we’ll dive into operators and how they work with different types.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Operators are symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Python supports several categories of operators: - Arithmetic - Comparison - Logical - Assignment - Bitwise - Membership - Identity

docs.title: 2. Arithmetic Operators
docs.text:
Used for basic math operations. 

x = 10
y = 3

print(x + y)  # 13 (Addition)
print(x - y)  # 7  (Subtraction)
print(x * y)  # 30 (Multiplication)
print(x / y)  # 3.333... (Division)
print(x // y) # 3 (Floor Division)
print(x % y)  # 1 (Modulus / Remainder)
print(x ** y) # 1000 (Exponentiation)

docs.title: 3. Comparison Operators
docs.text:
Used to compare values (result is True or False). 

x = 5
y = 10

print(x == y)  # False (Equal to)
print(x != y)  # True  (Not equal to)
print(x > y)   # False (Greater than)
print(x < y)   # True  (Less than)
print(x >= 5)  # True  (Greater or equal)
print(y <= 10) # True  (Less or equal)

docs.title: 4. Logical Operators
docs.text:
Used to combine conditional statements. 

a = True
b = False

print(a and b) # False (Both must be True)
print(a or b)  # True  (At least one True)
print(not a)   # False (Negation)

docs.title: 5. Assignment Operators
docs.text:
Used to assign values to variables. 

x = 10
x += 5   # same as x = x + 5
print(x) # 15

x -= 3   # x = x - 3 → 12
x *= 2   # x = x * 2 → 24
x /= 4   # x = x / 4 → 6.0
x %= 4   # x = x % 4 → 2.0
x **= 3  # x = x ** 3 → 8.0

docs.title: 6. Bitwise Operators
docs.text:
Work on binary (bit-level) data. 

x = 6   # 110 in binary
y = 3   # 011 in binary

print(x & y)  # 2 (AND → 010)
print(x | y)  # 7 (OR  → 111)
print(x ^ y)  # 5 (XOR → 101)
print(~x)     # -7 (NOT → flips bits)
print(x << 1) # 12 (Left shift → 1100)
print(x >> 1) # 3  (Right shift → 011)

docs.title: 7. Membership Operators
docs.text:
Used to test if a value exists in a sequence. 

fruits = ["apple", "banana"]

print("apple" in fruits)   # True
print("orange" not in fruits) # True

docs.title: 8. Identity Operators
docs.text:
Used to compare object references (memory addresses). 

a = [1, 2, 3]
b = [1, 2, 3]
c = a

print(a is b)     # False (different objects, same content)
print(a == b)     # True  (same values)
print(a is c)     # True  (same object reference)

docs.title: 9. Operator Precedence
docs.text:
Some operators are evaluated before others (like in math).

Order of precedence (highest to lowest): 1. () → Parentheses 2. ** → Exponent 3. *, /, //, % → Multiplication/division 4. +, - → Addition/subtraction 5. Comparison (==, <, >, etc.) 6. Logical (not, and, or)

Example:

result = 2 + 3 * 4
print(result)  # 14, because multiplication happens before addition

docs.title: 10. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know how to use Python’s operators: arithmetic, comparison, logical, assignment, bitwise, membership, and identity. In the next chapter, we’ll explore working with strings in detail.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Strings are one of the most commonly used data types in Python. They represent sequences of characters and are used for storing text.

docs.title: 2. Creating Strings
docs.text:
Strings can be created with single quotes, double quotes, or triple quotes:

s1 = 'Hello'
s2 = "World"
s3 = """This is
a multi-line string."""

docs.title: 3. Accessing Characters
docs.text:
Strings are sequences, so you can access characters using indexes:

word = "Python"
print(word[0])   # P
print(word[-1])  # n (last character)

docs.title: 4. String Slicing
docs.text:
You can extract substrings using slices:

word = "Python"
print(word[0:3])   # Pyt
print(word[2:])    # thon
print(word[:4])    # Pyth
print(word[-3:])   # hon

docs.title: 5. Common String Operations
docs.text:
• Concatenation:
print("Hello " + "World")  # Hello World
  • Repetition:
print("Hi! " * 3)  # Hi! Hi! Hi!
  • Length:
print(len("Python"))  # 6

docs.title: 6. Useful String Methods
docs.text:
text = "  python programming  "

print(text.upper())    # "  PYTHON PROGRAMMING  "
print(text.lower())    # "  python programming  "
print(text.strip())    # "python programming"
print(text.replace("python", "java"))  # "  java programming  "
print(text.split())    # ['python', 'programming']
print("-".join(["a", "b", "c"]))       # "a-b-c"

docs.title: 7. String Searching
docs.text:
sentence = "Learning Python is fun"
print("Python" in sentence)     # True
print(sentence.find("Python"))  # 9 (index where found)

docs.title: 8. Escape Sequences
docs.text:
Special characters can be written with a backslash:

print("Line1\nLine2")   # newline
print("Hello\tWorld")   # tab
print("She said \"Hi\"") # quotes inside string

docs.title: 9. f-Strings (String Interpolation)
docs.text:
Introduced in Python 3.6+, f-strings allow inserting variables directly:

name = "Alice"
age = 25
print(f"My name is {name} and I am {age} years old.")

docs.title: 10. Raw Strings
docs.text:
Useful for paths and regular expressions:

path = r"C:\Users\Name\Documents"
print(path)  # C:\Users\Name\Documents

docs.title: 11. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know how to work with strings: indexing, slicing, methods, and formatting. In the next chapter, we’ll cover escape characters and raw strings in more detail.

docs.title: Chapter 22: Escape Characters and Raw Strings
1. Introduction
docs.text: Sometimes you need special characters inside strings, like a newline or a tab. Python uses escape sequences to represent these characters. A raw string can be used when you want to ignore escape sequences.

docs.title: 2. What is an Escape Character?
docs.text:
• An escape character starts with a backslash (\).
  • It tells Python to treat the next character in a special way.

docs.title: 3. Common Escape Sequences
docs.text:
print("Hello\nWorld")   # Newline
print("Hello\tWorld")   # Tab
print("She said \"Hi\"") # Double quotes inside string
print('It\'s Python')   # Single quote inside string
print("C:\\Users\\Name") # Backslash itself

Output:

Hello
World
Hello   World
She said "Hi"
It's Python
C:\Users\Name

docs.title: 4. Multiline Strings
docs.text:
You can also use triple quotes (""" or ''') to handle multi-line text without needing \n:

text = """Line one
Line two
Line three"""
print(text)

docs.title: 5. Unicode and Special Characters
docs.text:
Python strings support Unicode. You can include characters using escape sequences:

print("\u03C0")  # π (Greek letter pi)
print("\u00A9")  # © symbol

docs.title: 6. Raw Strings
docs.text:
• A raw string is created by prefixing with r or R.
  • Escape sequences inside raw strings are not processed. 
path = r"C:\Users\Name\Documents"
print(path)  # C:\Users\Name\Documents

Without r:

path = "C:\Users\Name\Documents"
print(path)  # Error or unexpected result

docs.title: 7. When to Use Raw Strings
docs.text:
• File paths in Windows (C:\...).
  • Regular expressions (\d, \s, etc.).
  • Any time you want Python to treat backslashes literally.

docs.title: 8. Common Mistakes
docs.text: • Forgetting to escape backslashes: python print("C:\new_folder") # Error or unwanted behavior Better: python print("C:\\new_folder") # Escaped backslash print(r"C:\new_folder") # Raw string

docs.title: 9. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand escape characters and raw strings. In the next chapter, we’ll dive into lists, one of Python’s most versatile data types.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: A list is an ordered, changeable collection of items. Lists are one of the most commonly used data structures in Python because they are flexible and easy to use.

docs.title: 2. Creating Lists
docs.text:
Lists are defined using square brackets []:

fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
mixed = [1, "hello", 3.14, True]

docs.title: 3. Accessing List Elements
docs.text:
Use indexes (starting at 0):

fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
print(fruits[0])   # apple
print(fruits[-1])  # cherry (last element)

docs.title: 4. Modifying Lists
docs.text:
Lists are mutable, meaning you can change them:

fruits[1] = "blueberry"
print(fruits)  # ['apple', 'blueberry', 'cherry']

docs.title: 5. Adding Items
docs.text:
• Append to the end:
fruits.append("orange")
  • Insert at a position:
fruits.insert(1, "mango")

docs.title: 6. Removing Items
docs.text:
fruits.remove("apple")   # remove by value
print(fruits)

fruits.pop(1)            # remove by index
print(fruits)

last = fruits.pop()      # remove last item
print(last)

fruits.clear()           # remove all items
print(fruits)  # []

docs.title: 7. List Slicing
docs.text:
numbers = [10, 20, 30, 40, 50]
print(numbers[1:3])  # [20, 30]
print(numbers[:3])   # [10, 20, 30]
print(numbers[2:])   # [30, 40, 50]
print(numbers[::-1]) # reversed list

docs.title: 8. Checking Membership
docs.text:
fruits = ["apple", "banana"]
print("apple" in fruits)   # True
print("mango" not in fruits) # True

docs.title: 9. Iterating Over a List
docs.text:
for fruit in ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]:
    print(fruit)

docs.title: 10. Useful List Methods
docs.text:
numbers = [3, 1, 4, 1, 5]

print(len(numbers))      # 5
print(numbers.count(1))  # 2
print(numbers.index(4))  # 2
numbers.sort()
print(numbers)           # [1, 1, 3, 4, 5]
numbers.reverse()
print(numbers)           # [5, 4, 3, 1, 1]

docs.title: 11. Nested Lists
docs.text:
Lists can contain other lists:

matrix = [
    [1, 2, 3],
    [4, 5, 6],
    [7, 8, 9]
]
print(matrix[1][2])  # 6

docs.title: 12. Copying Lists
docs.text:
Be careful when copying lists:

a = [1, 2, 3]
b = a
b[0] = 99
print(a)  # [99, 2, 3] (changes reflected!)

# Correct way:
c = a.copy()
c[0] = 42
print(a)  # [99, 2, 3]
print(c)  # [42, 2, 3]

docs.title: 13. When to Use Lists
docs.text:
• When you need an ordered collection.
  • When you need to frequently modify elements.
  • For storing sequences of data like names, scores, or items.

docs.title: 14. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand how to create, access, modify, and use lists. In the next chapter, we’ll explore tuples, which are similar to lists but immutable.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text:
A tuple is an ordered collection of items, similar to a list. The key difference is that tuples are immutable — once created, their elements cannot be changed.

Tuples are often used when you want to group data that should not change.

docs.title: 2. Creating Tuples
docs.text:
Tuples use parentheses ():

numbers = (1, 2, 3)
fruits = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
mixed = (1, "hello", 3.14, True)

A tuple with one item needs a trailing comma:

single = (5,)
print(type(single))  # <class 'tuple'>

docs.title: 3. Accessing Elements
docs.text:
Like lists, tuples use indexes:

colors = ("red", "green", "blue")
print(colors[0])   # red
print(colors[-1])  # blue

docs.title: 4. Immutability of Tuples
docs.text:
Tuples cannot be changed after creation:

colors = ("red", "green", "blue")
# colors[0] = "yellow"  # ❌ TypeError

But you can reassign the variable to a new tuple:

colors = ("yellow", "green", "blue")

docs.title: 5. Tuple Operations
docs.text:
• Concatenation:
a = (1, 2)
b = (3, 4)
print(a + b)  # (1, 2, 3, 4)
  • Repetition:
print(("hi",) * 3)  # ('hi', 'hi', 'hi')
  • Membership:
print(2 in (1, 2, 3))  # True

docs.title: 6. Tuple Slicing
docs.text:
numbers = (10, 20, 30, 40, 50)
print(numbers[1:3])   # (20, 30)
print(numbers[:3])    # (10, 20, 30)
print(numbers[::-1])  # (50, 40, 30, 20, 10)

docs.title: 7. Tuple Methods
docs.text:
Tuples have only two methods (since they are immutable):

nums = (1, 2, 2, 3)
print(nums.count(2))  # 2
print(nums.index(3))  # 3

docs.title: 8. Nested Tuples
docs.text:
Tuples can contain other tuples:

nested = ((1, 2), (3, 4), (5, 6))
print(nested[1][0])  # 3

docs.title: 9. Packing and Unpacking
docs.text:
You can pack values into a tuple and unpack them into variables:

person = ("Alice", 25, "Engineer")

name, age, job = person
print(name)  # Alice
print(age)   # 25
print(job)   # Engineer

docs.title: 10. When to Use Tuples
docs.text:
• When you need immutable data.
  • When you want to use a collection as a dictionary key (lists cannot be keys, but tuples can).
  • For grouping related items together, like (latitude, longitude).

docs.title: 11. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand tuples: how to create them, access them, and why immutability is important. In the next chapter, we’ll explore sets, which are collections of unique items.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: A set is an unordered collection of unique items. Sets are useful when you want to store values without duplicates or perform mathematical set operations.

docs.title: 2. Creating Sets
docs.text:
Sets use curly braces {} or the set() function:

numbers = {1, 2, 3, 3, 4}
print(numbers)  # {1, 2, 3, 4}  (duplicates removed)

empty_set = set()  # correct way

⚠️ {} creates an empty dictionary, not a set.

docs.title: 3. Adding and Removing Elements
docs.text:
fruits = {"apple", "banana"}

fruits.add("cherry")
print(fruits)  # {'apple', 'banana', 'cherry'}

fruits.remove("banana")  # ❌ KeyError if not found
fruits.discard("pear")   # ✅ safe, no error if not found

popped = fruits.pop()    # removes a random element
print(popped)

docs.title: 4. Checking Membership
docs.text:
animals = {"cat", "dog", "bird"}
print("cat" in animals)   # True
print("lion" not in animals) # True

docs.title: 5. Set Operations
docs.text:
Sets support union, intersection, difference, and symmetric difference:

a = {1, 2, 3}
b = {3, 4, 5}

print(a | b)   # Union → {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}
print(a & b)   # Intersection → {3}
print(a - b)   # Difference → {1, 2}
print(a ^ b)   # Symmetric difference → {1, 2, 4, 5}

docs.title: 6. Updating Sets
docs.text:
a = {1, 2}
a.update([2, 3, 4])
print(a)  # {1, 2, 3, 4}

docs.title: 7. Frozen Sets
docs.text:
A frozenset is an immutable set:

fs = frozenset([1, 2, 3])
# fs.add(4)  # ❌ Error: frozenset is immutable

You can use frozensets as dictionary keys or store them in other sets.

docs.title: 8. Iterating Through Sets
docs.text:
colors = {"red", "green", "blue"}
for color in colors:
    print(color)

(Remember: order is not guaranteed.)

docs.title: 9. When to Use Sets
docs.text:
• Removing duplicates from a collection.
  • Checking membership quickly.
  • Performing mathematical set operations.
  • Using frozensets for immutable collections.

docs.title: 10. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand sets and frozensets. In the next chapter, we’ll explore dictionaries, Python’s key-value data structure.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: A dictionary in Python is a collection of key-value pairs. Each key must be unique, and it maps to a value. Dictionaries are powerful for storing structured data.

docs.title: 2. Creating Dictionaries
docs.text:
person = {"name": "Alice", "age": 25, "city": "London"}
print(person)

empty_dict = {}
another = dict(name="Bob", age=30)

docs.title: 3. Accessing Values
docs.text:
Access a value by its key:

print(person["name"])   # Alice

Using .get() avoids errors if the key doesn’t exist:

print(person.get("job", "Not specified"))  # Not specified

docs.title: 4. Adding and Updating Entries
docs.text:
person["job"] = "Engineer"   # add new key-value pair
person["age"] = 26           # update existing key
print(person)

docs.title: 5. Removing Entries
docs.text:
person.pop("city")      # remove by key
print(person)

person.popitem()        # removes last inserted pair
print(person)

del person["name"]      # delete by key
print(person)

person.clear()          # remove all items
print(person)           # {}

docs.title: 6. Iterating Through Dictionaries
docs.text:
person = {"name": "Alice", "age": 25}

# keys
for key in person:
    print(key)

# values
for value in person.values():
    print(value)

# key-value pairs
for key, value in person.items():
    print(key, ":", value)

docs.title: 7. Checking Keys
docs.text:
person = {"name": "Alice", "age": 25}
print("name" in person)     # True
print("job" not in person)  # True

docs.title: 8. Dictionary Methods
docs.text:
person = {"name": "Alice", "age": 25}

print(person.keys())    # dict_keys(['name', 'age'])
print(person.values())  # dict_values(['Alice', 25])
print(person.items())   # dict_items([('name', 'Alice'), ('age', 25)])

copy_person = person.copy()

docs.title: 9. Nested Dictionaries
docs.text:
Dictionaries can contain other dictionaries:

students = {
    "A001": {"name": "Alice", "age": 20},
    "A002": {"name": "Bob", "age": 22}
}
print(students["A001"]["name"])  # Alice

docs.title: 10. Dictionary Comprehensions
docs.text:
squares = {x: x*x for x in range(5)}
print(squares)  # {0: 0, 1: 1, 2: 4, 3: 9, 4: 16}

docs.title: 11. When to Use Dictionaries
docs.text:
• When data needs to be accessed by a key (not an index).
  • For structured records (student info, product details).
  • For fast lookups and updates.

docs.title: 12. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand dictionaries: how to create, access, update, and use them effectively. In the next chapter, we’ll cover booleans and logic in Python.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text:
A boolean is a data type with only two possible values: True or False. Booleans are the foundation of decision-making in programming.

In Python, booleans often appear as the result of comparisons or logical operations.

docs.title: 2. Boolean Values
docs.text:
x = True
y = False
print(x)        # True
print(type(x))  # <class 'bool'>

docs.title: 3. Comparisons that Return Booleans
docs.text:
print(5 > 3)   # True
print(10 == 2) # False
print(7 <= 7)  # True

docs.title: 4. The bool() Function
docs.text:
Any value can be converted to a boolean using bool().

  • Falsy values (evaluated as False):
  • 0, 0.0
  • "" (empty string)
  • [], {}, () (empty collections)
  • None

  • False

  • Everything else is True.

Examples:

print(bool(0))       # False
print(bool(""))      # False
print(bool("hi"))    # True
print(bool([1, 2]))  # True

docs.title: 5. Logical Operators
docs.text:
Logical operators combine boolean values.

a = True
b = False

print(a and b)  # False
print(a or b)   # True
print(not a)    # False

docs.title: 6. Combining Comparisons
docs.text:
You can use logical operators with comparisons:

x = 10
print(x > 5 and x < 20)   # True
print(x < 5 or x == 10)   # True
print(not(x == 10))       # False

docs.title: 7. Operator Precedence with Booleans
docs.text:
Order of evaluation: 1. not 2. and 3. or

Example:

print(True or False and False)   # True (and is evaluated first)

docs.title: 8. Identity and Membership in Boolean Contexts
docs.text:
fruits = ["apple", "banana"]

print("apple" in fruits)     # True
print("cherry" not in fruits) # True

a = [1, 2, 3]
b = a
c = [1, 2, 3]

print(a is b)  # True
print(a is c)  # False

docs.title: 9. Practical Examples
docs.text:
age = 18
has_id = True

if age >= 18 and has_id:
    print("Access granted")
else:
    print("Access denied")

docs.title: 10. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand booleans, comparisons, and logical operators. In the next chapter, we’ll explore if statements, the first step into control flow.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: The if statement is used to make decisions in Python. It allows your program to execute certain code only if a condition is true.

docs.title: 2. Basic if Statement
docs.text:
age = 18

if age >= 18:
    print("You are an adult")

Output:

You are an adult

docs.title: 3. Indentation Matters
docs.text:
Python uses indentation (spaces) to define blocks of code.

❌ Wrong:

if True:
print("Hello")   # Error: expected an indented block

✅ Correct:

if True:
    print("Hello")

docs.title: 4. Using Comparison Operators in if
docs.text:
temperature = 25

if temperature > 30:
    print("It's hot!")
if temperature < 10:
    print("It's cold!")
if temperature == 25:
    print("Perfect weather!")

docs.title: 5. if with Boolean Variables
docs.text:
is_logged_in = True

if is_logged_in:
    print("Welcome back!")

docs.title: 6. if with Expressions
docs.text:
Any expression that evaluates to True or False can be used:

name = "Alice"

if name:   # non-empty strings are True
    print("Name provided")

docs.title: 7. Nested if Statements
docs.text:
You can put an if inside another if:

age = 20
has_id = True

if age >= 18:
    if has_id:
        print("Access granted")

docs.title: 8. Common Mistakes
docs.text:
• Forgetting the colon (:) after the condition.
  • Misusing = instead of ==:
x = 5
if x == 5:   # ✅ correct
    print("x is 5")

# if x = 5:  # ❌ invalid

docs.title: 9. Practical Example
docs.text:
password = "python123"
user_input = "python123"

if user_input == password:
    print("Login successful")

docs.title: 10. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know how to use if statements for decision-making. In the next chapter, we’ll expand on this with elif and else clauses.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: The if statement checks a single condition. But in real programs, you often need to check multiple possibilities. That’s where elif (else if) and else come in.

docs.title: 2. The else Clause
docs.text:
else runs when all previous conditions are false.

age = 16

if age >= 18:
    print("You are an adult")
else:
    print("You are a minor")

Output:

You are a minor

docs.title: 3. The elif Clause
docs.text:
elif lets you check additional conditions.

score = 85

if score >= 90:
    print("Grade: A")
elif score >= 80:
    print("Grade: B")
elif score >= 70:
    print("Grade: C")
else:
    print("Grade: F")

Output:

Grade: B

docs.title: 4. Multiple elif Clauses
docs.text:
You can chain as many elif clauses as needed, but only one else.

temperature = 25

if temperature > 30:
    print("Hot")
elif temperature > 20:
    print("Warm")
elif temperature > 10:
    print("Cool")
else:
    print("Cold")

docs.title: 5. Order of Conditions Matters
docs.text:
Python checks conditions top to bottom. As soon as one condition is true, the rest are ignored.

x = 15

if x > 10:
    print("Greater than 10")
elif x > 5:
    print("Greater than 5")

Output:

Greater than 10

docs.title: 6. Nested Conditionals vs elif
docs.text:
Instead of multiple nested if statements, elif makes code cleaner.

❌ Nested:

x = 10
if x >= 0:
    if x == 0:
        print("Zero")
    else:
        print("Positive")

✅ Better:

x = 10
if x < 0:
    print("Negative")
elif x == 0:
    print("Zero")
else:
    print("Positive")

docs.title: 7. Using Boolean Operators with if
docs.text:
You can combine conditions using and, or, and not.

age = 20
has_id = True

if age >= 18 and has_id:
    print("Access granted")

docs.title: 8. Short-Circuiting
docs.text:
Python stops evaluating conditions as soon as the result is known.

x = 0

# This won't cause ZeroDivisionError
if x != 0 and (10 / x > 1):
    print("Condition met")

Here, since x != 0 is False, Python never checks the second condition.

docs.title: 9. Membership Tests in Conditions
docs.text:
You can use in and not in directly.

fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]

if "apple" in fruits:
    print("Apple found")
elif "orange" not in fruits:
    print("No orange here")

docs.title: 10. Conditional Expressions (Ternary Operator)
docs.text:
Python has a compact way to write if-else inside an expression:

age = 18
status = "adult" if age >= 18 else "minor"
print(status)  # adult

docs.title: 11. Common Beginner Mistakes
docs.text:
• Forgetting the colon (:): python if x > 5 # ❌ SyntaxError
  • Using = instead of ==: python if x = 5: # ❌ invalid
  • Misordering conditions: python if x > 0: print("Positive") elif x > 10: # ❌ unreachable, since >10 is already >0 print("Greater than 10")

docs.title: 12. Best Practices
docs.text:
• Keep conditions simple and readable.
  • Avoid deep nesting; prefer elif.
  • Use parentheses in complex conditions for clarity.
  • If multiple conditions lead to the same action, group them with or.

docs.title: 13. Practical Example
docs.text:
marks = 72

if marks >= 90:
    grade = "A"
elif marks >= 75:
    grade = "B"
elif marks >= 50:
    grade = "C"
else:
    grade = "F"

print("Your grade is", grade)

docs.title: 14. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand how to use elif and else, along with advanced condition-handling techniques. In the next chapter, we’ll look at nested conditionals in more detail.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: A nested conditional is an if statement inside another if. They let you check conditions within conditions, useful when decisions depend on multiple factors.

docs.title: 2. Basic Nested if
docs.text:
age = 20
has_id = True

if age >= 18:
    if has_id:
        print("Access granted")

docs.title: 3. Nested if-else
docs.text:
x = 15

if x > 0:
    if x % 2 == 0:
        print("Positive even number")
    else:
        print("Positive odd number")
else:
    print("Not a positive number")

docs.title: 4. Multiple Levels of Nesting
docs.text:
You can nest deeper, but code becomes harder to read.

x = 12

if x > 0:
    if x < 20:
        if x % 3 == 0:
            print("Positive number < 20 and divisible by 3")

docs.title: 5. Combining Conditions Instead
docs.text:
Often you can avoid deep nesting with logical operators.

❌ Nested:

if age >= 18:
    if has_ticket:
        print("Welcome")

✅ Better:

if age >= 18 and has_ticket:
    print("Welcome")

docs.title: 6. When Nested Conditionals are Useful
docs.text:
• Complex decision-making where one condition depends on another.
  • Validating multiple layers of requirements (e.g., login + role check).
  • When clarity is better served by nesting than by a long combined condition.

docs.title: 7. Common Mistakes
docs.text:
• Too many nested levels → code becomes unreadable.
  • Forgetting to properly indent nested blocks.
  • Overusing nesting where elif or logical operators would be simpler.

docs.title: 8. Practical Example
docs.text:
username = "admin"
password = "secret"

if username == "admin":
    if password == "secret":
        print("Login successful")
    else:
        print("Wrong password")
else:
    print("Unknown user")

docs.title: 9. Best Practices
docs.text:
• Limit nesting to 2–3 levels maximum.
  • Refactor deeply nested conditionals into functions.
  • Use elif or compound conditions for clarity when possible.

docs.title: 10. Next Steps
