docs.text: ✅ You now understand nested conditionals and when to use them. In the next chapter, we’ll explore while loops, which allow repeating actions while a condition is true.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: A while loop is used to repeat a block of code as long as a condition is true. It is useful when you don’t know in advance how many times to repeat an action.

docs.title: 2. Basic while Loop
docs.text:
count = 1

while count <= 5:
    print("Count:", count)
    count += 1

Output:

Count: 1
Count: 2
Count: 3
Count: 4
Count: 5

docs.title: 3. Infinite Loops
docs.text:
If the condition never becomes false, the loop runs forever.

while True:
    print("This will run forever")

⚠️ Stop infinite loops with Ctrl + C in terminal.

docs.title: 4. Using a Break Condition
docs.text:
Always ensure there’s a way for the loop to end.

x = 0
while x < 10:
    if x == 5:
        break
    print(x)
    x += 1

docs.title: 5. Using else with while
docs.text:
The else block runs when the loop ends normally (not by break).

x = 1
while x <= 3:
    print(x)
    x += 1
else:
    print("Loop finished successfully")

Output:

1
2
3
Loop finished successfully

docs.title: 6. Nested while Loops
docs.text:
You can put a while loop inside another while loop.

i = 1
while i <= 2:
    j = 1
    while j <= 3:
        print(f"i={i}, j={j}")
        j += 1
    i += 1

docs.title: 7. Common Mistakes
docs.text:
• Forgetting to update the loop variable → infinite loop.
  • Using = instead of == in the condition.
  • Forgetting the colon (:) after the condition.

docs.title: 8. Practical Examples
docs.text:
• Countdown timer:
n = 5
while n > 0:
    print(n)
    n -= 1
print("Blast off!")
  • Input validation:
password = ""
while password != "python123":
    password = input("Enter password: ")
print("Access granted")

docs.title: 9. When to Use while Loops
docs.text:
• When the number of iterations is unknown ahead of time.
  • For waiting on user input, file availability, or network events.
  • For loops that depend on conditions instead of a fixed range.

docs.title: 10. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know how to use while loops, avoid infinite loops, and apply break/else. In the next chapter, we’ll explore for loops, which are often used when the number of iterations is known.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: A for loop is used to iterate over a sequence of items (like a list, string, or range). It is the most common looping construct in Python when you know the number of iterations in advance.

docs.title: 2. Basic for Loop
docs.text:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]

for fruit in fruits:
    print(fruit)

Output:

apple
banana
cherry

docs.title: 3. Iterating Over Strings
docs.text:
Strings are sequences, so you can loop through characters:

for char in "Python":
    print(char)

docs.title: 4. Using the range() Function
docs.text:
range() generates a sequence of numbers.

for i in range(5):
    print(i)

Output:

0
1
2
3
4

You can specify start, stop, and step:

for i in range(2, 10, 2):
    print(i)   # 2, 4, 6, 8

docs.title: 5. Looping with Index and Value
docs.text:
Use enumerate() when you need both index and value.

fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]

for index, fruit in enumerate(fruits):
    print(index, fruit)

docs.title: 6. Nested for Loops
docs.text:
for i in range(2):
    for j in range(3):
        print(f"i={i}, j={j}")

docs.title: 7. Using else with for
docs.text:
The else block runs if the loop finishes normally (not broken).

for i in range(3):
    print(i)
else:
    print("Loop completed")

docs.title: 8. Breaking Out of Loops
docs.text:
for i in range(10):
    if i == 5:
        break
    print(i)

docs.title: 9. Skipping Iterations with continue
docs.text:
for i in range(5):
    if i == 2:
        continue
    print(i)

Output:

0
1
3
4

docs.title: 10. Practical Examples
docs.text:
• Summing numbers:
total = 0
for i in range(1, 6):
    total += i
print("Sum =", total)
  • Iterating over a dictionary:
person = {"name": "Alice", "age": 25}
for key, value in person.items():
    print(key, "=", value)

docs.title: 11. When to Use for Loops
docs.text:
• Iterating over lists, strings, or dictionaries.
  • When you know or can define the range of iterations.
  • For cleaner, more readable code compared to while loops.

docs.title: 12. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand for loops and how to iterate over sequences. In the next chapter, we’ll explore the range() function in more detail.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: The range() function is commonly used in for loops to generate a sequence of numbers. It doesn’t actually create a full list in memory but instead produces numbers on demand, making it efficient.

docs.title: 2. Basic Usage
docs.text:
range(stop) generates numbers from 0 up to stop (exclusive).

for i in range(5):
    print(i)

Output:

0
1
2
3
4

docs.title: 3. Specifying Start and Stop
docs.text:
You can also give a starting value:

for i in range(2, 6):
    print(i)

Output:

2
3
4
5

docs.title: 4. Using Step
docs.text:
The third parameter is the step (increment).

for i in range(0, 10, 2):
    print(i)

Output:

0
2
4
6
8

docs.title: 5. Negative Steps
docs.text:
You can loop backwards with a negative step.

for i in range(10, 0, -2):
    print(i)

Output:

10
8
6
4
2

docs.title: 6. Using range() Outside of Loops
docs.text:
You can convert a range to a list or tuple:

print(list(range(5)))   # [0, 1, 2, 3, 4]
print(tuple(range(3)))  # (0, 1, 2)

docs.title: 7. Checking Membership in range
docs.text:
You can check if a number is inside a range:

print(5 in range(10))    # True
print(15 in range(10))   # False

docs.title: 8. Large Ranges are Efficient
docs.text:
Even huge ranges don’t take up memory:

r = range(1, 1_000_000)
print(len(r))     # 999999
print(r[100])     # 101

⚡ The values are generated on demand.

docs.title: 9. Common Mistakes
docs.text:
• Forgetting that the stop value is excluded: python for i in range(5): print(i) # Outputs 0–4, not 0–5
  • Using the wrong step (causes empty loops): python for i in range(5, 0, 1): # ❌ won't run print(i) # Step should be -1 if going down

docs.title: 10. Practical Examples
docs.text:
• Printing even numbers:
for i in range(0, 11, 2):
    print(i)
  • Countdown:
for i in range(5, 0, -1):
    print(i)
print("Go!")

docs.title: 11. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand how to use range() with start, stop, and step values. In the next chapter, we’ll look at loop control statements like break, continue, and pass.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text:
Python provides special statements to control the flow of loops: - break → exits the loop early - continue → skips the current iteration - pass → does nothing (placeholder)

These give you more fine-grained control over loop execution.

docs.title: 2. The break Statement
docs.text:
break stops the loop entirely, even if the condition is still true.

for i in range(10):
    if i == 5:
        break
    print(i)

Output:

0
1
2
3
4

docs.title: 3. The continue Statement
docs.text:
continue skips the rest of the current iteration and goes to the next one.

for i in range(5):
    if i == 2:
        continue
    print(i)

Output:

0
1
3
4

docs.title: 4. The pass Statement
docs.text:
pass is a placeholder that does nothing. It is useful when you need a syntactically valid block but don’t want to add code yet.

for i in range(3):
    if i == 1:
        pass  # do nothing
    print("i =", i)

docs.title: 5. break in while Loops
docs.text:
x = 0
while True:
    print(x)
    x += 1
    if x > 3:
        break

docs.title: 6. continue in while Loops
docs.text:
x = 0
while x < 5:
    x += 1
    if x == 3:
        continue
    print(x)

Output:

1
2
4
5

docs.title: 7. Nested Loops with break
docs.text:
break only exits the innermost loop.

for i in range(2):
    for j in range(3):
        if j == 1:
            break
        print(i, j)

Output:

0 0
1 0

docs.title: 8. Practical Examples
docs.text:
• Finding a number in a list:
numbers = [1, 3, 5, 7, 9]

for num in numbers:
    if num == 5:
        print("Found 5!")
        break
  • Skipping odd numbers:
for i in range(1, 6):
    if i % 2 != 0:
        continue
    print(i)

docs.title: 9. Common Mistakes
docs.text:
• Using break when you only meant to skip an iteration (use continue).
  • Overusing pass instead of writing meaningful code.
  • Forgetting that break only exits the current loop, not all loops.

docs.title: 10. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand how to use break, continue, and pass to control loop behavior. In the next chapter, we’ll explore nested loops and how to work with loops inside loops effectively.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: A nested loop is a loop inside another loop. They are useful when working with multi-dimensional data (like matrices), comparing items from two collections, or performing repeated tasks across multiple dimensions.

docs.title: 2. Basic Nested for Loop
docs.text:
for i in range(3):
    for j in range(2):
        print(f"i={i}, j={j}")

Output:

i=0, j=0
i=0, j=1
i=1, j=0
i=1, j=1
i=2, j=0
i=2, j=1

docs.title: 3. Nested while Loops
docs.text:
i = 1
while i <= 2:
    j = 1
    while j <= 3:
        print(f"i={i}, j={j}")
        j += 1
    i += 1

docs.title: 4. Mixed Loops (for + while)
docs.text:
for char in ["A", "B"]:
    i = 0
    while i < 2:
        print(char, i)
        i += 1

docs.title: 5. Nested Loops with Lists (Matrices)
docs.text:
matrix = [[1, 2], [3, 4], [5, 6]]
for row in matrix:
    for value in row:
        print(value)

Output:

1
2
3
4
5
6

docs.title: 6. Using break and continue in Nested Loops
docs.text:
break exits the innermost loop; continue skips to the next iteration of the innermost loop.

for i in range(3):
    for j in range(3):
        if j == 1:
            break  # stops inner loop only
        print(i, j)

docs.title: 7. Practical Example — Multiplication Table
docs.text:
for i in range(1, 4):
    for j in range(1, 4):
        print(i * j, end=" ")
    print()

Output:

1 2 3 
2 4 6 
3 6 9

docs.title: 8. Performance Considerations
docs.text: Nested loops increase time complexity multiplicatively (e.g., O(n*m) or O(n^2) for two nested loops of size n). For large inputs, consider algorithmic improvements or using libraries (NumPy, itertools).

docs.title: 9. Common Mistakes and Tips
docs.text:
• Forgetting to reset inner-loop counters in while loops.
  • Excessive nesting → harder to read and maintain. Break logic into functions when nesting gets deep.
  • Remember to maintain correct indentation.

docs.title: 10. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand nested loops and how to use them effectively. Next chapter: Comprehensions, a concise way to create collections in Python.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Comprehensions provide a concise and readable way to create lists, sets, or dictionaries from existing iterables. They often replace simple loops and temporary containers.

docs.title: 2. List Comprehensions: Basic Example
docs.text:
squares = [x * x for x in range(5)]
print(squares)  # [0, 1, 4, 9, 16]

docs.title: 3. List Comprehensions with Condition
docs.text:
evens = [x for x in range(10) if x % 2 == 0]
print(evens)  # [0, 2, 4, 6, 8]

docs.title: 4. Nested Comprehensions
docs.text:
pairs = [(i, j) for i in range(2) for j in range(3)]
print(pairs)  # [(0,0), (0,1), (0,2), (1,0), (1,1), (1,2)]

docs.title: 5. Set Comprehensions
docs.text:
unique_mod3 = {x % 3 for x in range(10)}
print(unique_mod3)  # {0, 1, 2}

docs.title: 6. Dictionary Comprehensions
docs.text:
squares = {x: x * x for x in range(5)}
print(squares)  # {0:0, 1:1, 2:4, 3:9, 4:16}

docs.title: 7. Generator Expressions
docs.text:
Generator expressions use () and produce values on demand (lazy evaluation):

gen = (x * x for x in range(3))
for value in gen:
    print(value)

Output:

0
1
4

docs.title: 8. Readability and When to Use
docs.text: Comprehensions are great for simple transformations and filters. Avoid stuffing too much logic in a single comprehension — prefer readable code over cleverness.

docs.title: 9. Common Pitfalls
docs.text:
• Overly complex comprehensions (hard to read).
  • Reusing the same variable name inside comprehension leading to confusion.
  • Generator expressions are single-use (they are iterators).

docs.title: 10. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand comprehensions for lists, sets, dicts, and generators. Next chapter: Defining and calling functions.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: A function is a reusable block of code that performs a specific task. Functions improve modularity and reduce repetition.

docs.title: 2. Defining a Simple Function
docs.text:
def greet():
    print("Hello, world!")

docs.title: 3. Calling a Function
docs.text: greet()  # Output: Hello, world!

docs.title: 4. Functions with Parameters
docs.text:
def greet(name):
    print("Hello,", name)

greet("Alice")

docs.title: 5. Returning Values
docs.text:
def add(a, b):
    return a + b

result = add(2, 3)
print(result)  # 5

docs.title: 6. Multiple Return Values (Tuples)
docs.text:
def min_and_max(values):
    return min(values), max(values)

low, high = min_and_max([1, 2, 3])
print(low, high)  # 1 3

docs.title: 7. Docstrings and Function Help
docs.text:
def square(x):
    "Return square of x."
    return x * x

help(square)  # shows docstring

docs.title: 8. Pure Functions vs Side Effects
docs.text:
• Pure function: same input → same output, no side effects.
  • Side effect: writing to file, modifying global variables, etc. Prefer pure functions when possible.

docs.title: 9. Best Practices
docs.text:
• Use descriptive function names.
  • Keep functions short and focused (single responsibility).
  • Write docstrings for public functions.

docs.title: 10. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know how to define and call functions. Next chapter: Function arguments and return values.

docs.title: Chapter 38: Function Arguments and Return Values
1. Introduction
docs.text: Functions take inputs (arguments) and may produce outputs (return values). Understanding how arguments are passed and how returns work is essential.

docs.title: 2. Positional Arguments
docs.text:
def multiply(a, b):
    return a * b

print(multiply(2, 3))  # 6

docs.title: 3. Keyword Arguments (Named Arguments)
docs.text:
def greet(name, age):
    print(f"Hello {name}, you are {age} years old")

greet(age=30, name="Alice")

docs.title: 4. Default Return Value (None)
docs.text:
If a function does not return explicitly, it returns None.

def say_hi():
    print("Hi")

result = say_hi()
print(result)  # None

docs.title: 5. Returning Multiple Values
docs.text:
Functions can return tuples which can be unpacked.

def stats(numbers):
    return min(numbers), max(numbers), sum(numbers)

low, high, total = stats([1, 2, 3])
print(low, high, total)

docs.title: 6. Arguments vs Parameters
docs.text:
• Parameters are names in function definition.
  • Arguments are actual values passed to the function.

docs.title: 7. Type Hints (Optional)
docs.text:
Python supports optional type hints for better readability and tooling:

def add(a: int, b: int) -> int:
    return a + b

docs.title: 8. Best Practices
docs.text:
• Validate arguments where appropriate.
  • Return early if inputs are invalid.
  • Keep return types consistent for easier use.

docs.title: 9. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand arguments and return values. Next: Default and keyword arguments.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Default values and keyword arguments let you write flexible functions with sensible defaults and clear calls.

docs.title: 2. Default Arguments Example
docs.text:
def greet(name='Guest'):
    print('Hello,', name)

greet()          # Hello, Guest
greet('Alice')   # Hello, Alice

docs.title: 3. Keyword Arguments Example
docs.text:
def describe(name, age):
    print(f"{name} is {age} years old")

describe(age=25, name='Bob')

docs.title: 4. Mixing Positional and Keyword Arguments
docs.text:
Positional arguments must come before keyword arguments when calling a function:

def display(a, b, c):
    print(a, b, c)

display(1, c=3, b=2)

docs.title: 5. Mutable Default Argument Pitfall
docs.text:
Avoid using mutable defaults (lists, dicts) directly.

Bad example:

def add_item(item, collection=[]):
    collection.append(item)
    return collection

Better pattern:

def add_item(item, collection=None):
    if collection is None:
        collection = []
    collection.append(item)
    return collection

docs.title: 6. Best Practices
docs.text:
• Use immutable default values when possible.
  • Use keyword arguments to improve readability for functions with many parameters.

docs.title: 7. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand default and keyword arguments. Next: *args and **kwargs.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: *args and **kwargs let functions accept an arbitrary number of positional and keyword arguments respectively.

docs.title: 2. Using *args (Positional Varargs)
docs.text:
def add_numbers(*args):
    return sum(args)

print(add_numbers(1, 2, 3, 4))  # 10

docs.title: 3. Using **kwargs (Keyword Varargs)
docs.text:
def print_info(**kwargs):
    for key, value in kwargs.items():
        print(key, '=', value)

print_info(name='Alice', age=30)

docs.title: 4. Mixing Positional, args, Defaults, *kwargs
docs.text:
Parameter order: positional, args, default parameters, *kwargs.

def func(a, *args, b=10, **kwargs):
    print(a, args, b, kwargs)

func(1, 2, 3, b=20, x=99)

docs.title: 5. Unpacking with * and **
docs.text:
You can unpack sequences and dicts when calling functions:

nums = [1, 2, 3]
print(add_numbers(*nums))  # unpacks list into positional args

options = {'name': 'Bob', 'age': 25}
print_info(**options)  # unpacks dict into keyword args

docs.title: 6. Practical Example
docs.text:
def shopping_cart(*items, **details):
    print('Items:', items)
    print('Details:', details)

shopping_cart('apple', 'banana', payment='card', discount=True)

docs.title: 7. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand args and kwargs. Next chapter: Scope and lifetime of variables*.

docs.title: Chapter 41: Scope and Lifetime of Variables
1. Introduction
docs.text: Scope defines where a variable can be accessed in a program. Lifetime defines how long the variable exists in memory.

docs.title: 2. Local Scope
docs.text:
Variables defined inside a function are local to that function.

def my_func():
    x = 10  # local variable
    print(x)

my_func()
# print(x)  # ❌ Error: x not defined here

docs.title: 3. Global Scope
docs.text:
Variables defined outside any function are global.

y = 20  # global variable

def show():
    print(y)

show()
print(y)  # accessible everywhere

docs.title: 4. Modifying Globals Inside Functions
docs.text:
Use global keyword.

count = 0

def increment():
    global count
    count += 1

increment()
print(count)  # 1

docs.title: 5. Enclosing Scope (Nonlocal)
docs.text:
Nested functions can access variables from the enclosing function.

def outer():
    x = "outer"
    def inner():
        nonlocal x
        x = "inner"
    inner()
    print(x)

outer()  # inner

docs.title: 6. Built-in Scope
docs.text:
Python has reserved keywords and built-in functions (like len, print).

print(len([1,2,3]))

docs.title: 7. Variable Lifetime
docs.text:
• Local variables live only during function execution.
  • Global variables live as long as the program runs.

docs.title: 8. Best Practices
docs.text:
• Minimize use of global variables.
  • Prefer returning values instead of modifying globals.
  • Use meaningful variable names.

docs.title: 9. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand scope and lifetime of variables. In the next chapter, we’ll learn about importing modules.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Modules are Python files containing reusable code (functions, classes, variables). You can import them into your program using the import statement.

docs.title: 2. Importing a Whole Module
docs.text:
import math
print(math.sqrt(16))  # 4.0

docs.title: 3. Importing Specific Items
docs.text:
from math import pi, sqrt
print(pi)      # 3.14159...
print(sqrt(25)) # 5.0

docs.title: 4. Using Aliases
docs.text:
import numpy as np
print(np.array([1,2,3]))

docs.title: 5. Importing All Items (Not Recommended)
docs.text:
from math import *
print(sin(0))

⚠️ Can cause name conflicts.

docs.title: 6. Importing Custom Modules
docs.text:
If you have a file mymath.py:

# mymath.py
def square(x): return x*x

Use it in another script:

import mymath
print(mymath.square(5))

docs.title: 7. Reloading Modules
docs.text:
Sometimes you need to reload a module (during development).

import importlib, mymath
importlib.reload(mymath)

docs.title: 8. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know how to import modules. In the next chapter, we’ll learn about creating your own modules.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: A module is just a Python file with functions, variables, or classes. Creating your own modules helps organize code.

docs.title: 2. Creating a Module
docs.text:
1. Create a file mymath.py:
def add(a, b):
    return a + b
def subtract(a, b):
    return a - b
  1. Use it in another file:
import mymath
print(mymath.add(2,3))

docs.title: 3. Module Search Path
docs.text:
Python looks for modules in: - Current directory - PYTHONPATH environment variable - Standard library path 

import sys
print(sys.path)

docs.title: 4. Organizing with Packages
docs.text:
A package is a directory with an __init__.py file. Example structure:

mypackage/
    __init__.py
    module1.py
    module2.py

Use:

from mypackage import module1

docs.title: 5. Best Practices
docs.text:
• Use lowercase filenames.
  • Group related functions in one module.
  • Keep modules small and focused.

docs.title: 6. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know how to create your own modules. In the next chapter, we’ll revisit virtual environments.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: We first saw virtual environments in Chapter 16. Here, we’ll reinforce their importance in real-world projects.

docs.title: 2. Why Use Virtual Environments?
docs.text:
• Isolate dependencies for each project.
  • Prevent version conflicts.
  • Keep global Python clean.

docs.title: 3. Creating a Virtual Environment
docs.text: python3 -m venv venv

docs.title: 4. Activating the Environment
docs.text:
• Windows (cmd): venv\Scripts\activate
  • PowerShell: venv\Scripts\Activate.ps1
  • Linux/macOS: source venv/bin/activate

docs.title: 5. Installing Packages in Virtual Environments
docs.text:
pip install requests

Packages stay isolated inside venv/lib/.

docs.title: 6. Freezing Dependencies
docs.text:
pip freeze > requirements.txt

Recreate environment:

pip install -r requirements.txt

docs.title: 7. Deactivating and Removing
docs.text:
deactivate
rm -rf venv

docs.title: 8. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand how to use virtual environments effectively. In the next chapter, we’ll revisit installing packages with pip.

docs.title: Chapter 45: Installing Packages with pip Revisited
1. Introduction
docs.text: We learned about pip in Chapter 15. Now we’ll go deeper into best practices for package management in real projects.

docs.title: 2. Installing a Specific Version
docs.text: pip install requests==2.31.0

docs.title: 3. Upgrading and Downgrading
docs.text:
pip install --upgrade requests
pip install requests==2.28.0

docs.title: 4. Uninstalling Packages
docs.text: pip uninstall requests

docs.title: 5. Listing Installed Packages
docs.text: pip list

docs.title: 6. Searching for Packages
docs.text: pip search flask

docs.title: 7. Using requirements.txt
docs.text:
Create:

pip freeze > requirements.txt

Install from file:

pip install -r requirements.txt

docs.title: 8. Using pip in Virtual Environments
docs.text: Always activate your environment before installing packages. This keeps dependencies isolated.

docs.title: 9. Common Issues
docs.text:
• Permission errors → use --user or virtual environments.
  • Version conflicts → check pipdeptree or use virtual environments.

docs.title: 10. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand advanced pip usage. In the next chapter, we’ll learn about reading text files.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Python provides built-in tools to read text files. Reading files is essential for working with stored data.

docs.title: 2. Opening a File
docs.text:
Use open() with mode 'r' (read).

file = open("example.txt", "r")
content = file.read()
print(content)
file.close()

docs.title: 3. Using with Statement
docs.text:
Always use with for automatic closing.

with open("example.txt", "r") as f:
    content = f.read()
    print(content)

docs.title: 4. Reading Line by Line
docs.text:
with open("example.txt", "r") as f:
    for line in f:
        print(line.strip())

docs.title: 5. readlines() Method
docs.text:
with open("example.txt") as f:
    lines = f.readlines()
print(lines)

docs.title: 6. readline() Method
docs.text:
with open("example.txt") as f:
    line = f.readline()
    print(line)

docs.title: 7. Handling File Not Found
docs.text:
try:
    with open("missing.txt") as f:
        print(f.read())
except FileNotFoundError:
    print("File not found")

docs.title: 8. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know how to read text files. Next: Writing text files.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Writing to files allows saving output for later use. Python uses open() with different modes.

docs.title: 2. Writing with 'w' Mode
docs.text:
Overwrites existing content or creates new file.

with open("output.txt", "w") as f:
    f.write("Hello, file!")

docs.title: 3. Appending with 'a' Mode
docs.text:
Adds content to end of file.

with open("output.txt", "a") as f:
    f.write("\nAnother line")

docs.title: 4. Writing Multiple Lines
docs.text:
lines = ["First line\n", "Second line\n"]
with open("output.txt", "w") as f:
    f.writelines(lines)

docs.title: 5. Ensuring Flush and Close
docs.text: Files are closed automatically when using with. Otherwise, call f.close() manually.

docs.title: 6. Handling Encoding
docs.text:
with open("unicode.txt", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    f.write("Olá, mundo!")

docs.title: 7. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know how to write to files. Next: Working with binary files.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Text files store characters, but binary files store bytes. Examples include images, executables, and audio files.

docs.title: 2. Reading Binary Files
docs.text:
with open("image.jpg", "rb") as f:
    data = f.read()
    print(len(data), "bytes")

docs.title: 3. Writing Binary Files
docs.text:
with open("copy.jpg", "wb") as f:
    f.write(data)

docs.title: 4. Copying Files
docs.text:
with open("image.jpg", "rb") as src:
    with open("copy.jpg", "wb") as dst:
        dst.write(src.read())

docs.title: 5. When to Use Binary Mode
docs.text:
• Images
  • Audio files
  • Pickled objects
  • Any non-text data

docs.title: 6. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know how to work with binary files. Next: Using context managers.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Context managers handle setup and cleanup automatically. The most common use is file handling with with.

docs.title: 2. Basic Example
docs.text:
with open("example.txt", "r") as f:
    data = f.read()
print("File closed?", f.closed)

docs.title: 3. Custom Context Managers
docs.text:
Create your own with a class implementing __enter__ and __exit__.

class MyResource:
    def __enter__(self):
        print("Resource acquired")
        return self
    def __exit__(self, exc_type, exc_val, exc_tb):
        print("Resource released")

with MyResource() as r:
    print("Using resource")

docs.title: 4. Contextlib Module
docs.text:
Simplify creation with contextlib.

from contextlib import contextmanager

@contextmanager
def simple_manager():
    print("Start")
    yield
    print("End")

with simple_manager():
    print("Inside block")

docs.title: 5. Benefits
docs.text:
• Automatic cleanup
  • Cleaner code
  • Error safety

docs.title: 6. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand context managers. Next: Handling exceptions.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Exceptions are errors that occur during execution. Python provides try/except blocks to handle them gracefully.

docs.title: 2. Basic try-except
docs.text:
try:
    x = 10 / 0
except ZeroDivisionError:
    print("Cannot divide by zero")

docs.title: 3. Multiple Except Clauses
docs.text:
try:
    num = int("abc")
except ValueError:
    print("Invalid number")
except ZeroDivisionError:
    print("Division error")

docs.title: 4. Catching Any Exception
docs.text:
try:
    risky_code()
except Exception as e:
    print("Error:", e)

docs.title: 5. Using else with try
docs.text:
try:
    x = 10 / 2
except ZeroDivisionError:
    print("Error")
else:
    print("Success:", x)

docs.title: 6. Finally Block
docs.text:
try:
    file = open("example.txt")
finally:
    file.close()

docs.title: 7. Best Practices
docs.text:
• Catch specific exceptions first.
  • Avoid bare except: unless necessary.
  • Clean up resources with finally or context managers.

docs.title: 8. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand exception handling. Next: Using finally and else in more detail.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Python's try statement can include optional else and finally blocks: - else runs if no exception occurs. - finally always runs, regardless of whether an exception occurs.

docs.title: 2. Using else
docs.text:
try:
    x = 10 / 2
except ZeroDivisionError:
    print("Division by zero")
else:
    print("No error, result =", x)

docs.title: 3. Using finally
docs.text:
try:
    f = open("example.txt", "w")
    f.write("Hello")
finally:
    f.close()
    print("File closed")

docs.title: 4. Combining else and finally
docs.text:
try:
    x = int("42")
except ValueError:
    print("Invalid number")
else:
    print("Conversion succeeded:", x)
finally:
    print("Done processing")

docs.title: 5. Why Use else?
docs.text: Keeps success-path logic separate from error handling.

docs.title: 6. Why Use finally?
docs.text: Guarantees cleanup (e.g., closing files, releasing resources).

docs.title: 7. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand how to use else and finally in exception handling. Next: Common built-in exceptions.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Python provides many built-in exception types. Knowing the most common ones helps write better error handling.

docs.title: 2. Common Exceptions
docs.text:
• ValueError → wrong value
int("abc")  # ValueError
  • TypeError → wrong type
"2" + 3  # TypeError
  • IndexError → invalid list index
[1, 2][5]  # IndexError
  • KeyError → missing dictionary key
{"a": 1}["b"]  # KeyError
  • ZeroDivisionError → divide by zero
10 / 0
  • FileNotFoundError → missing file
open("missing.txt")
  • ImportError / ModuleNotFoundError → module not found
import nonexistent
  • AttributeError → attribute doesn’t exist
"hello".not_a_method()

docs.title: 3. Handling Multiple Exceptions
docs.text:
try:
    result = 10 / 0
except (ZeroDivisionError, ValueError) as e:
    print("Error:", e)

docs.title: 4. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know common built-in exceptions. Next: Dates and times in Python.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Python's datetime module helps work with dates and times.

docs.title: 2. Getting Current Date and Time
docs.text:
from datetime import datetime
now = datetime.now()
print(now)

docs.title: 3. Formatting Dates
docs.text: print(now.strftime("%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S"))

docs.title: 4. Parsing Strings into Dates
docs.text:
from datetime import datetime
dt = datetime.strptime("2023-01-01", "%Y-%m-%d")
print(dt)

docs.title: 5. Timedelta for Arithmetic
docs.text:
from datetime import timedelta
tomorrow = now + timedelta(days=1)
print("Tomorrow:", tomorrow)

docs.title: 6. Date Objects
docs.text:
from datetime import date
d = date.today()
print(d)

docs.title: 7. Time Objects
docs.text:
from datetime import time
t = time(14, 30)
print(t)

docs.title: 8. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know how to handle dates and times. Next: Math operations.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Python has built-in operators and the math module for advanced operations.

docs.title: 2. Built-in Arithmetic
docs.text:
print(5 + 3)  # 8
print(5 ** 2) # 25

docs.title: 3. math Module Functions
docs.text:
import math
print(math.sqrt(16))  # 4.0
print(math.factorial(5))  # 120

docs.title: 4. Trigonometry
docs.text: print(math.sin(math.pi / 2))  # 1.0

docs.title: 5. Constants
docs.text:
print(math.pi)
print(math.e)

docs.title: 6. Rounding and Floor/Ceil
docs.text:
print(math.floor(3.7))  # 3
print(math.ceil(3.7))   # 4

docs.title: 7. Random Numbers
docs.text:
import random
print(random.randint(1, 10))

docs.title: 8. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know math operations in Python. Next: Working with JSON files.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is a lightweight format for storing and exchanging data. Python provides the json module.

docs.title: 2. Writing JSON
docs.text:
import json

data = {"name": "Alice", "age": 25}
with open("data.json", "w") as f:
    json.dump(data, f)

docs.title: 3. Reading JSON
docs.text:
with open("data.json") as f:
    obj = json.load(f)
print(obj)

docs.title: 4. Converting Between JSON and Strings
docs.text:
s = json.dumps(data)
print(s)
obj = json.loads(s)
print(obj)

docs.title: 5. Handling Non-Serializable Data
docs.text:
Custom objects need conversion before JSON encoding.

from datetime import datetime
data = {"time": datetime.now().isoformat()}

docs.title: 6. Pretty Printing JSON
docs.text: print(json.dumps(data, indent=4))

docs.title: 7. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know how to read and write JSON in Python. Next: Configuration files.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Configuration files store program settings. Python supports multiple formats like .ini, .yaml, .json, and environment variables.

docs.title: 2. Using INI Files with configparser
docs.text:
import configparser

config = configparser.ConfigParser()
config.read("settings.ini")

print(config["DEFAULT"]["username"])

Example settings.ini:

[DEFAULT]
username = admin
password = secret

docs.title: 3. Writing INI Files
docs.text:
config["NEW"] = {"key": "value"}
with open("settings.ini", "w") as f:
    config.write(f)

docs.title: 4. JSON Config Files
docs.text:
import json
with open("config.json") as f:
    cfg = json.load(f)
print(cfg)

docs.title: 5. YAML Config Files (via PyYAML)
docs.text:
import yaml
with open("config.yaml") as f:
    cfg = yaml.safe_load(f)
print(cfg)

docs.title: 6. Best Practices
docs.text:
• Keep secrets (like passwords) out of config files.
  • Use environment variables for sensitive info.
  • Document your config structure.

docs.title: 7. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know how to use configuration files. Next: Environment variables.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Environment variables are dynamic values set outside Python. They are often used for configuration and secrets.

docs.title: 2. Accessing Environment Variables
docs.text:
import os
print(os.getenv("HOME"))

docs.title: 3. Setting Environment Variables
docs.text:
Linux/macOS:

export API_KEY=12345

Windows (cmd):

set API_KEY=12345

docs.title: 4. Using in Python
docs.text:
api_key = os.getenv("API_KEY", "default_value")
print(api_key)

docs.title: 5. Modifying in Python
docs.text:
os.environ["DEBUG"] = "true"
print(os.environ["DEBUG"])

docs.title: 6. Best Practices
docs.text:
• Use env vars for secrets (API keys, passwords).
  • Don’t hardcode sensitive values in code.
  • Consider libraries like python-dotenv for .env files.

docs.title: 7. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know environment variables. Next: Introduction to Object-Oriented Programming (OOP).

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) is a paradigm based on "objects". Objects combine data (attributes) and behavior (methods).

docs.title: 2. Why OOP?
docs.text:
• Encapsulation: group data + functions.
  • Reusability: write once, reuse with inheritance.
  • Abstraction: hide complexity.
  • Modularity: divide large programs into manageable parts.

docs.title: 3. Classes and Objects
docs.text:
class Dog:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name

    def bark(self):
        print(self.name, "says woof!")

my_dog = Dog("Buddy")
my_dog.bark()

docs.title: 4. OOP Terminology
docs.text:
• Class → blueprint.
  • Object (instance) → created from class.
  • Attributes → variables inside objects.
  • Methods → functions inside objects.

docs.title: 5. Procedural vs OOP
docs.text:
• Procedural → functions and data separate.
  • OOP → functions + data bundled together.

docs.title: 6. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand the basics of OOP. Next: Creating classes and objects.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: In Python, classes define the structure of objects. Objects are instances of classes.

docs.title: 2. Creating a Class
docs.text:
class Car:
    def drive(self):
        print("The car is moving")

docs.title: 3. Creating Objects
docs.text:
my_car = Car()
my_car.drive()

docs.title: 4. Adding Attributes
docs.text:
class Car:
    def __init__(self, brand, model):
        self.brand = brand
        self.model = model

car = Car("Toyota", "Corolla")
print(car.brand, car.model)

docs.title: 5. Multiple Objects
docs.text:
car1 = Car("Ford", "Fiesta")
car2 = Car("Tesla", "Model 3")
print(car1.brand, car2.brand)

docs.title: 6. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know how to create classes and objects. Next: The __init__ constructor.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: The __init__ method is a special constructor in Python classes. It runs automatically when a new object is created.

docs.title: 2. Basic Example
docs.text:
class Person:
    def __init__(self, name, age):
        self.name = name
        self.age = age

p = Person("Alice", 30)
print(p.name, p.age)

docs.title: 3. Default Values
docs.text:
class Person:
    def __init__(self, name, age=18):
        self.name = name
        self.age = age

p = Person("Bob")
print(p.name, p.age)  # Bob 18

docs.title: 4. Why Use init?
docs.text:
• Initialize attributes.
  • Set default states.
  • Validate input during object creation.

docs.title: 5. Best Practices
docs.text:
• Keep __init__ simple.
  • Don’t overload it with logic — use helper methods.

docs.title: 6. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand the __init__ constructor. Next: Instance vs class variables.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Python classes can define two types of variables: - Instance variables → unique to each object. - Class variables → shared across all objects.

docs.title: 2. Instance Variables
docs.text:
Defined inside __init__ and tied to self.

class Dog:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name  # instance variable

d1 = Dog("Buddy")
d2 = Dog("Max")
print(d1.name, d2.name)

Output:

Buddy Max

docs.title: 3. Class Variables
docs.text:
Defined outside methods, shared by all objects.

class Dog:
    species = "Canine"  # class variable
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name

d1 = Dog("Buddy")
d2 = Dog("Max")
print(d1.species, d2.species)

Output:

Canine Canine

docs.title: 4. Modifying Instance vs Class Variables
docs.text:
d1.species = "Wolf"  # creates new instance variable
print(d1.species, d2.species)  # Wolf Canine

Dog.species = "Wolf"  # modifies class variable
print(d1.species, d2.species)  # Wolf Wolf

docs.title: 5. Best Practices
docs.text:
• Use instance variables for object-specific data.
  • Use class variables for constants or shared defaults.

docs.title: 6. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand instance vs class variables. Next: Methods and behaviors.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Methods define behaviors of objects. They are functions defined inside a class.

docs.title: 2. Instance Methods
docs.text:
The most common method type. Always include self.

class Dog:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name

    def bark(self):
        print(self.name, "says woof!")

dog = Dog("Buddy")
dog.bark()

docs.title: 3. Class Methods
docs.text:
Operate on the class itself, not instances. Use @classmethod.

class Dog:
    count = 0
    def __init__(self, name):
        Dog.count += 1
    @classmethod
    def get_count(cls):
        return cls.count

print(Dog.get_count())

docs.title: 4. Static Methods
docs.text:
Behave like regular functions but live in class namespace. Use @staticmethod.

class Math:
    @staticmethod
    def add(a, b):
        return a + b

print(Math.add(2, 3))

docs.title: 5. Special Methods
docs.text:
Python classes can override built-ins like __str__, __len__.

class Person:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name
    def __str__(self):
        return f"Person({self.name})"

p = Person("Alice")
print(p)

docs.title: 6. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now know about instance, class, static, and special methods. Next: Basic inheritance.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Inheritance allows a class (child) to reuse code from another class (parent).

docs.title: 2. Simple Inheritance
docs.text:
class Animal:
    def speak(self):
        print("Some sound")

class Dog(Animal):
    def speak(self):
        print("Woof!")

d = Dog()
d.speak()

docs.title: 3. Accessing Parent Methods
docs.text:
Use super().

class Animal:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name

class Dog(Animal):
    def __init__(self, name, breed):
        super().__init__(name)
        self.breed = breed

dog = Dog("Buddy", "Beagle")
print(dog.name, dog.breed)

docs.title: 4. Method Resolution Order (MRO)
docs.text:
Python supports multiple inheritance; MRO decides which method to call.

print(Dog.__mro__)

docs.title: 5. Best Practices
docs.text:
• Inherit when classes are logically related.
  • Prefer composition (has-a) if inheritance doesn’t fit well.

docs.title: 6. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand inheritance. Next: Encapsulation basics.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Encapsulation is about restricting access to certain data or methods in a class. Python uses naming conventions instead of strict enforcement.

docs.title: 2. Public Attributes
docs.text:
Accessible everywhere.

class Person:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name

p = Person("Alice")
print(p.name)

docs.title: 3. Protected Attributes
docs.text:
Prefix with _ (convention: treat as internal use).

class Person:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self._name = name

p = Person("Bob")
print(p._name)  # accessible but discouraged

docs.title: 4. Private Attributes
docs.text:
Prefix with __ triggers name mangling.

class Person:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.__name = name

p = Person("Eve")
# print(p.__name)  # ❌ AttributeError
print(p._Person__name)  # still accessible

docs.title: 5. Getters and Setters
docs.text:
Control access with methods.

class Person:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.__name = name
    def get_name(self):
        return self.__name
    def set_name(self, name):
        self.__name = name

docs.title: 6. Using @property
docs.text:
class Person:
    def __init__(self, age):
        self._age = age

    @property
    def age(self):
        return self._age

    @age.setter
    def age(self, value):
        if value >= 0:
            self._age = value

p = Person(20)
p.age = 30
print(p.age)

docs.title: 7. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You now understand encapsulation basics. Next: Mini project — Student and Course Manager.

docs.title: Chapter 65: Mini Project — Student and Course Manager
1. Introduction
docs.text: Let’s apply OOP concepts (classes, attributes, methods, inheritance, encapsulation) to build a small project.

docs.title: 2. Requirements
docs.text:
• Manage students and courses.
  • Add/remove students.
  • Enroll students in courses.
  • Show enrollments.

docs.title: 3. Student Class
docs.text:
class Student:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name
        self.courses = []
    def enroll(self, course):
        self.courses.append(course)

docs.title: 4. Course Class
docs.text:
class Course:
    def __init__(self, title):
        self.title = title
        self.students = []
    def add_student(self, student):
        self.students.append(student)

docs.title: 5. Manager Class
docs.text:
class Manager:
    def __init__(self):
        self.students = []
        self.courses = []
    def add_student(self, student):
        self.students.append(student)
    def add_course(self, course):
        self.courses.append(course)

docs.title: 6. Putting It Together
docs.text:
s1 = Student("Alice")
s2 = Student("Bob")
c1 = Course("Math")
c2 = Course("Science")

m = Manager()
m.add_student(s1)
m.add_student(s2)
m.add_course(c1)
m.add_course(c2)

s1.enroll(c1)
s2.enroll(c2)

print(s1.name, "enrolled in", [c.title for c in s1.courses])
print(s2.name, "enrolled in", [c.title for c in s2.courses])

docs.title: 7. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You built a small OOP project. Next: Capstone Project — File Manager CLI.

docs.title: Chapter 67: Zen of Python — Reflections from the Capstone
1. Introduction
docs.text:
At the heart of Python lies a guiding philosophy known as The Zen of Python, written by Tim Peters. You can see it by running:

import this

The Zen is a collection of 19 aphorisms that capture the spirit of Python’s design. In this chapter, we’ll revisit some key principles and connect them to what we practiced in the File Manager CLI Capstone Project.

docs.title: 🧘 “Simple is better than complex.”
docs.text: In our File Manager, we started with simple functions (read_file, write_file) before moving to OOP. Keeping it simple first allowed us to learn step by step without overwhelming complexity.

docs.title: 🧘 “Explicit is better than implicit.”
docs.text: When parsing CLI commands with argparse, we required clear arguments (list . or read notes.txt). This explicitness avoids ambiguity and makes the tool user-friendly.

docs.title: 🧘 “Errors should never pass silently.”
docs.text: In Chapter 6 (Error Handling), we made sure exceptions like FileNotFoundError were caught and explained to the user. A crashing CLI would frustrate users — clear error messages build trust.

docs.title: 🧘 “Readability counts.”
docs.text: Our OOP refactor (Chapter 7) grouped related operations inside the FileManager class. This improved readability and maintainability compared to scattered functions.

docs.title: 🧘 “Now is better than never.”
docs.text: By actually building a real project instead of endlessly learning theory, we embodied this principle. The File Manager wasn’t perfect, but finishing it gave us something real to improve upon.

docs.title: 3. Other Principles to Remember
docs.text:
• “There should be one—and preferably only one—obvious way to do it.” → We standardized commands (list, delete) rather than allowing too many variations.

  • “Errors should never pass silently. Unless explicitly silenced.” → We sometimes used try/except to catch specific cases, not hide everything.

  • “Namespaces are one honking great idea — let’s do more of those!” → Organizing our code into modules and a FileManager class gave us clarity.

docs.title: 4. Why the Zen Matters
docs.text:
• It goes beyond syntax and into philosophy of design.
  • Helps you make better decisions when structuring real projects.
  • Encourages writing code for humans first, machines second.

docs.title: 5. Final Thoughts
docs.text: The Zen of Python is not just theory — it’s a set of practical values. As you continue your Python journey, keep these principles in mind. They will help you write code that is clean, maintainable, and “Pythonic.”

docs.title: 6. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ With the Zen of Python as your guide, you’ve now completed Volume 1: Foundations. You are ready to move forward into Volume 2: Python for Web Development.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text:
In this capstone project, we will build a Command-Line Interface (CLI) File Manager. This project will tie together everything learned in Volume 1: Foundations: - Variables and data types - Control flow (if/else, loops) - Functions and modules - File handling (text, binary) - Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)

The goal is to simulate a real-world project while reinforcing Python fundamentals.

docs.title: 2. Why a File Manager?
docs.text: A file manager is a practical project because: - Every operating system uses files and directories. - It provides hands-on experience with file handling. - It combines multiple programming concepts in a meaningful way. - It can grow into a more advanced tool in later volumes (e.g., with GUIs, networking).

docs.title: 3. Project Objectives
docs.text: By the end of this project, learners will be able to: 1. Create a CLI tool using Python. 2. Navigate directories and manage files. 3. Handle user input and provide meaningful feedback. 4. Implement error handling for real-world scenarios. 5. Refactor procedural code into OOP.

docs.title: 4. Planned Features
docs.text: The File Manager CLI will support the following commands: - list → show files and directories in the current folder - create → create new files or directories - delete → remove files or directories - move → move files from one location to another - copy → copy files - read → display file contents - write → write new content into a file - search → find files by name or extension

docs.title: 5. Tools and Libraries
docs.text: We will use only the Python Standard Library: - os and os.path → file and directory operations - shutil → copy and move files - argparse → parsing command-line arguments - sys → handling errors and exits

docs.title: 6. Workflow
docs.text: The project will progress through these stages: 1. Basic CLI skeleton — learn how to handle commands. 2. File operations — implement read/write/delete. 3. Directory operations — implement list/create/move. 4. Search and filters — extend functionality. 5. Error handling — make it robust. 6. OOP refactor — turn it into a class-based design. 7. Enhancements — optional improvements.

docs.title: 7. Expected Outcome
docs.text: At the end of this capstone, you will have: - A working CLI tool you can run from the terminal. - Experience designing, building, and testing a larger program. - Confidence in applying Python fundamentals to real projects.

docs.title: 8. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ Now that we understand the project scope and goals, let’s move on to Chapter 2: Basic Structure, where we will set up the CLI entry point.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Before adding file operations, we need a skeleton CLI structure. This will allow the program to accept commands and arguments from the terminal.

docs.title: 2. Using argparse
docs.text:
We’ll use Python’s argparse library for handling command-line arguments.

import argparse

def main():
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description="File Manager CLI")
    parser.add_argument("command", help="Command to run (list, create, delete, etc.)")
    parser.add_argument("path", nargs="?", help="Target file or directory")

    args = parser.parse_args()
    print("Command:", args.command)
    print("Path:", args.path)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

Run from terminal:

python file_manager.py list .

Output:

Command: list
Path: .

docs.title: 3. Project Structure
docs.text:
capstone_file_manager/
    file_manager.py

docs.title: 4. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ Now we have a basic CLI structure that accepts commands. Next: Implementing file operations (read, write, delete).

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: File operations are core to any file manager. We’ll implement read, write, delete, copy, and move.

docs.title: 2. Reading a File
docs.text:
def read_file(path):
    try:
        with open(path, "r") as f:
            print(f.read())
    except FileNotFoundError:
        print("File not found")

docs.title: 3. Writing to a File
docs.text:
def write_file(path, content):
    with open(path, "w") as f:
        f.write(content)
    print("File written successfully")

docs.title: 4. Deleting a File
docs.text:
import os

def delete_file(path):
    try:
        os.remove(path)
        print("File deleted")
    except FileNotFoundError:
        print("File not found")

docs.title: 5. Copying and Moving Files
docs.text:
import shutil

def copy_file(src, dst):
    shutil.copy(src, dst)
    print("File copied")

def move_file(src, dst):
    shutil.move(src, dst)
    print("File moved")

docs.title: 6. Integrating with CLI
docs.text:
if args.command == "read":
    read_file(args.path)
elif args.command == "write":
    write_file(args.path, "Hello World")
elif args.command == "delete":
    delete_file(args.path)

docs.title: 7. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ File operations are implemented. Next: Directory operations (create, list, navigate).

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Directories organize files. Our CLI should allow: - Creating directories - Listing contents - Navigating paths

docs.title: 2. Creating Directories
docs.text:
import os

def create_directory(path):
    try:
        os.makedirs(path, exist_ok=True)
        print("Directory created")
    except Exception as e:
        print("Error:", e)

docs.title: 3. Listing Contents
docs.text:
def list_directory(path):
    try:
        for item in os.listdir(path):
            print(item)
    except FileNotFoundError:
        print("Directory not found")

docs.title: 4. Getting Current Working Directory
docs.text: print("Current directory:", os.getcwd())

docs.title: 5. Changing Directory (optional)
docs.text:
os.chdir("..")
print("Now in:", os.getcwd())

docs.title: 6. Integrating with CLI
docs.text:
if args.command == "list":
    list_directory(args.path or ".")
elif args.command == "mkdir":
    create_directory(args.path)

docs.title: 7. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ Directory operations are working. Next: Search and filters for files.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: A file manager should support searching files by name, extension, or size.

docs.title: 2. Searching by Name
docs.text:
def search_by_name(path, name):
    for root, dirs, files in os.walk(path):
        for file in files:
            if name in file:
                print(os.path.join(root, file))

docs.title: 3. Filtering by Extension
docs.text:
def search_by_extension(path, extension):
    for root, dirs, files in os.walk(path):
        for file in files:
            if file.endswith(extension):
                print(os.path.join(root, file))

docs.title: 4. Filtering by Size
docs.text:
def search_by_size(path, min_size):
    for root, dirs, files in os.walk(path):
        for file in files:
            file_path = os.path.join(root, file)
            if os.path.getsize(file_path) >= min_size:
                print(file_path)

docs.title: 5. Integrating with CLI
docs.text:
if args.command == "search":
    search_by_name(".", args.path)

docs.title: 6. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ We can now search and filter files. Next: Error handling to make the program more robust.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: A file manager should support searching files by name, extension, or size.

docs.title: 2. Searching by Name
docs.text:
def search_by_name(path, name):
    for root, dirs, files in os.walk(path):
        for file in files:
            if name in file:
                print(os.path.join(root, file))

docs.title: 3. Filtering by Extension
docs.text:
def search_by_extension(path, extension):
    for root, dirs, files in os.walk(path):
        for file in files:
            if file.endswith(extension):
                print(os.path.join(root, file))

docs.title: 4. Filtering by Size
docs.text:
def search_by_size(path, min_size):
    for root, dirs, files in os.walk(path):
        for file in files:
            file_path = os.path.join(root, file)
            if os.path.getsize(file_path) >= min_size:
                print(file_path)

docs.title: 5. Integrating with CLI
docs.text:
if args.command == "search":
    search_by_name(".", args.path)

docs.title: 6. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ We can now search and filter files. Next: Error handling to make the program more robust.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Robust programs handle errors gracefully. Our File Manager should never crash due to missing files or permission issues.

docs.title: 2. Handling Missing Files
docs.text:
def safe_delete(path):
    try:
        os.remove(path)
        print("Deleted", path)
    except FileNotFoundError:
        print("Error: File not found")
    except PermissionError:
        print("Error: Permission denied")

docs.title: 3. Wrapping File Operations
docs.text:
All file/directory operations should be wrapped in try/except.

def safe_read(path):
    try:
        with open(path) as f:
            print(f.read())
    except FileNotFoundError:
        print("File not found")
    except UnicodeDecodeError:
        print("Cannot decode file")

docs.title: 4. CLI Integration
docs.text:
if args.command == "delete":
    safe_delete(args.path)
elif args.command == "read":
    safe_read(args.path)

docs.title: 5. Best Practices
docs.text:
• Catch specific exceptions first.
  • Provide clear error messages.
  • Use logging in larger projects.

docs.title: 6. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ Our program is now more robust. Next: Refactor with OOP for better design.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: So far, our program has procedural functions. We will now refactor it into a FileManager class.

docs.title: 2. Creating FileManager Class
docs.text:
import os, shutil

class FileManager:
    def __init__(self, base_dir="."):
        self.base_dir = base_dir

    def list(self, path="."):
        try:
            for item in os.listdir(path):
                print(item)
        except Exception as e:
            print("Error:", e)

    def read(self, path):
        try:
            with open(path) as f:
                print(f.read())
        except Exception as e:
            print("Error:", e)

docs.title: 3. Adding More Methods
docs.text:
def write(self, path, content):
        with open(path, "w") as f:
            f.write(content)
        print("Written to", path)

    def delete(self, path):
        try:
            os.remove(path)
            print("Deleted", path)
        except Exception as e:
            print("Error:", e)

docs.title: 4. Using the Class in CLI
docs.text:
fm = FileManager()

if args.command == "list":
    fm.list(args.path or ".")
elif args.command == "read":
    fm.read(args.path)

docs.title: 5. Benefits of OOP Refactor
docs.text:
• Cleaner code.
  • Encapsulation of related functions.
  • Easier to extend.

docs.title: 6. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ We now use OOP for file management. Next: Enhancements to make it more user-friendly.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Once the core features work, we can add enhancements to improve usability.

docs.title: 2. Adding Logging
docs.text:
import logging

logging.basicConfig(filename="file_manager.log", level=logging.INFO)

def log_action(action, path):
    logging.info("%s: %s", action, path)

docs.title: 3. Adding Colors (optional)
docs.text:
def print_success(msg):
    print(f"\033[92m{msg}\033[0m")  # green

def print_error(msg):
    print(f"\033[91m{msg}\033[0m")  # red

docs.title: 4. Configuration File
docs.text:
Allow default directory or settings from config.json.

import json

with open("config.json") as f:
    config = json.load(f)
print("Default dir:", config["default_dir"])

docs.title: 5. Aliases for Commands
docs.text:
Instead of typing list, allow ls. This can be handled by mapping aliases.

aliases = {"ls": "list", "rm": "delete"}
command = aliases.get(args.command, args.command)

docs.title: 6. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ We added enhancements like logging, colors, and aliases. Next: Testing and debugging.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Testing ensures our program works as expected. Debugging helps us find and fix issues.

docs.title: 2. Manual Testing
docs.text:
Run commands from CLI:

python file_manager.py list .
python file_manager.py read test.txt
python file_manager.py delete test.txt

docs.title: 3. Unit Testing with unittest
docs.text:
import unittest
import os

class TestFileManager(unittest.TestCase):
    def test_write_and_read(self):
        fm = FileManager()
        fm.write("test.txt", "hello")
        self.assertTrue(os.path.exists("test.txt"))
        fm.read("test.txt")
        os.remove("test.txt")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    unittest.main()

docs.title: 4. Debugging with print and logging
docs.text:
print("Debug: entering function")

Better: use logging with debug level.

logging.debug("Entering write_file")

docs.title: 5. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ We can now test and debug our project. Next: Final wrap-up.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Congratulations! You have completed the File Manager CLI project.

docs.title: 2. What We Built
docs.text:
• File operations: read, write, delete, copy, move
  • Directory operations: create, list, navigate
  • Search and filters
  • Error handling
  • OOP refactor with FileManager class
  • Enhancements (logging, colors, aliases)
  • Testing and debugging

docs.title: 3. Example Usage
docs.text:
python file_manager.py list .
python file_manager.py create notes.txt
python file_manager.py write notes.txt "Hello World"
python file_manager.py read notes.txt
python file_manager.py search notes
python file_manager.py delete notes.txt

docs.title: 4. Possible Improvements
docs.text:
• Add GUI (Tkinter, PyQt, etc.)
  • Add networking (remote file management)
  • Add cloud integration (Google Drive, Dropbox)
  • Add version control (track file changes)

docs.title: 5. Lessons Learned
docs.text:
• How to structure a CLI project.
  • How to combine multiple Python concepts.
  • How to refactor procedural code into OOP.
  • How to handle real-world problems like errors and testing.

docs.title: 6. Next Steps
docs.text: ✅ You’ve finished the Capstone Project for Volume 1. Move forward to Volume 2: Python for Web Development to continue your journey!
